story:
WHAT IT IS

Diversity Multicultural Channel is a web TV/Radio station established to serve the needs of the ever growing migrant population in the Republic of Ireland to promote community and social integration, Social development and empowerment by bringing together Ireland's new communities to engage, debates on social, immigration and political and other issues concerning and affecting migrant people from across the globe who now call Ireland home. DTV platform has offerings of local integrated range of audience engagement opportunities to all members of ethnic minority communities across Ireland.

Multicultural Television Station in Ireland 

What We Need & 

This is the first leg of our campaign and We need to raise $55,000 to get all the things we need to set up and running. Roughly half of the amount will go toward purchasing quality equipment like cameras, editing software, etc. While the other half will fund a part-time technician with expertise in video recording and editing, hire creative talents, music and licensing, insurance, set design, mobile app, and more importantly we want a studio space.

BUT, these costs money, that's where you come in! Join us in our campaign and help us reach our goal otherwise this project will struggle to get off the ground. 

However, if we don't reach our goal at the end of this campaign, any funds raised will go toward studio hire and getting basic equipment to begin production of a few shows while we plan a second phase of funding exercise. But If we get super-duper lucky and exceed this goal amount! Then, Hallelujah! Extra funds will go towards organising training workshops for migrant women and youth. Please see Migrant Media Funds section on our website.

A small contribution from you can go a long way in helping us meet our funding goal. Donate Now At Any Level in the Right Hand Column to Support DTV. You will be helping to launch a project that will change the media landscape in Ireland for ever! A project aiming to promote integration and inclusion and empowerment to migrant people in Ireland!  

 

What You Get

For our generous backers we truly appreciate your donation regardless of amount. To show our appreciation we have selected perks for you to choose from at what level you contribute at. You will be thanked on our website and social media, or get a signed copy of any title of my books listed on amazon.com, You can choose to get free DTV T-Shirt, be Executive Producer of our Kid's Club segment, Executive Producer of the Youth segment, be Sponsor of DTV for an entire year(dtv sponsored by you), a patron of DTV, be named Grand Patron and more.  Check out our perks list for more detail.

The Impact

Ireland is now a diverse country but the media does not represent this fact and there is always the issue of under representation of migrants in the media especially when there are currently no alternative channels to accommodate us and allow us to air our views. But DTV is trying to change that conversation and so I really cannot emphasize enough how important your support is to the future of ethnic minority media practices in Ireland.
More importantly, Ireland not only need an alternative to full-scale television station for ethnic-minorities but one that is owned and run by members of it's new communities like DTV. Ireland truly deserve to have this service kind of service platform just like our neighbouring UK counterparts for example - with our very own hosts who are immigrants or from migrant backgrounds producing and presenting ethnic grassroots programs to the general Irish public. This is our shot to give Ireland this unique service opportunity and help to build DTV into a force to be reckoned with ---an alternative media in Ireland that empowers people to discuss what matters to them without fear of prejudice.


Risks & Challenges

This is a massive & wildly imaginative project. Launching a TV channel on any scale regardless of whether it is online or offline costs money and will take time to grow. But just like the "journey of a thousand miles", we have already begun with the first step in creating the website and the awareness on social media where we have our followers and audience. We have even started podcasting on the radio section. There are no real risks but we face a challenge of not been able purchase all the equipment that are needed should we fail to reach our target or raise substantial amount from this campaign.

That’s why I'm relying on your support to Diversity Television.

PLEASE CLICK ON THE DONATION LEVEL OF YOUR CHOICE TO YOUR RIGHT.

How Can You Help?

DONATE: Dig deep, donate what you can to DTV funding campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and let people know about Diversity TV Ireland.
  • Please use the Indiegogo powerful share tools to spread the word!
  • Using these tools to helps us reach others who care about what DTV stand for and the work that we do.  Visit the website: www.diversitytvireland.com

TELL OTHERS: Follow us on twitter, be inspired, and tell the people you know who are passionate about community, multiculturalism, diversity, & integration, or just those who love TV and online media or maybe they just love to help.

Spread the word! Use the instagram, twitter, facebook and other social media outlet to help us get the word out about this campaign.

Help us Build a Multicultural Television Station for Ireland. Thank you for your support.

We Want to Hear from You!Send us any questions you have about this campaign at diversitymediaireland@gmail.com We promise to do our best to answer all your queries! Please don't leave this page without making a donation. 

PLEASE NOTE: That we also  take donations offline. Thank You!

story:
Thank you all of our donors and supportors of this campaign. We raised 7% of our goal, but then Rotary club of Katy have agreed to collaborate with us. Our campaign has been matched with $1,500 to be raised by Interact clubs of Katy. 

We have sponsored education, living cost, food and clothing for two kids in Sindhupalchowk district, who are now studying in Jugal Boarding School in Grade 6. We hope to continue this project until these children graduate from High school to be able to apply for vocational training, higher education, and jobs. 

We expect continuous support from you all. Thank you all again. - Suraj Bhattarai, Chris Gibson and Rotary Katy/Rotaract WH Katy family

STORIES FROM THE GROUND

"During our Earthquake relief mission in Thulosirubari VDC, Sindhupalchowk, we met these 2 children, raised by their father after they lost their mother nearly a decade ago. Unfortunately, their father also lost his life in the recent Earthquake making their life a series of misery. They are now been taken care by their uncle who is financial weak and already has 6 children of his own. They have no shelter either." Dr. Prabhat Sapkota, one of our local partners from B.P. Koirala Institute of Health Sciences Nepal and a medical doctor involved in the relief mission, shared his experiences from Sindhupalchowk, the district with more than 4,000 deaths.  We would like to disburse a part of our fund for the rehabilitation of these 2 children.

Ramita Rokka, 12, and Anil Rokka, 10, from Thulosirubari, Sindhupalchowk district, have been orphaned by the Earthquake. Photo courtesy: Dr. Prabhat Sapkota 

This story is just one of the thousand other stories which represent children's vulnerability brought about by the Earthquake. According to the Secretary of the Village Development Committee (VDC) and In-charge of the Health post, there are about 20 such children in the village.

WHAT WE'RE GOING TO DO

 West Houston/Katy Rotaract Club members expressing solidarity to Nepal Project

Young professionals from Houston, Texas, are very concerned about this natural disaster in Nepal. Representing the Rotary clubs, Rotaract clubs and several other social organizations of Houston, we would like to contribute to the rehabilitation process of disaster victims.

Our goal is to provide scholarships, educational materials, medical supplies, immunization and psychosocial counseling for at least 10 children who have been orphaned by this Earthquake.

 Our additional goal is to reach out to at least 10 households in Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha districts to help rehabilitate Earthquake disabled children. 

Suraj is returning to Nepal to work on the ground from late June 2015, whereas a team of at least 3 other volunteers from USA led by Chris Gibson, are going to Nepal in Winter to teach and support the underprivileged children.

Disbursement of Fund 

(Beneficiaries: 20 Orphans/Disabled Children)

  1. Elementary to High School Level Books. 3 books to each child. Minimum NRS 600 per child. Total cost ~$150.  
  2. Backpack, Notebooks, Pen and other stationery.  Minimum NRS 1000 per child. Total cost ~$250. 
  3. School Admission fees for 20 children. Minimum NRS 2000 per child. Total cost ~$400. (If we surpass our goal, it can be extended to more children) 
  4. One-year Scholarship for 20 children. Minimum NRS 200 per month per child. Total cost ~$500.(If goal is surpassed, scholarship can be extended to more children)
  5. Medical Bills for Sick/Injured Orphans or Disabled. Minimum NRS 1000 per child. Total cost ~$300. (it depends upon number of sick kids). 
  6. Braces, Sling and Support for Neck/Back/Knees/Foot. Each item can cost up to NPR 500. Total cost ~$200.
  7. Crutches, Wheelchair, Prosthesis or other Orthopedic supplies depending upon the disability of children. Up to NPR 1,500 per item. Total cost ~$600.
  8. Free Immunization (Full doses of Hepatitis B/DPT/MMR/Polio and Vitamin A based on the age) and Deworming prophylaxis with Albendazole. Minimum NPR 1000 per child. Total cost ~$300.
  9. Toothbrush+Toothpaste for 1 year. NRS 300 per child. Total ~$60.
  10. Tampon (Sanitary pad) and Towel. NRS 300 per child. Total ~$60.
  11. Symposium: Psychological Counseling, Motivation lectures, Yoga classes and Adolescent Health Education. Logistic management cost minimum NPR 30,000. Total cost ~$350.
  12. Incentives for Caretakers (Guardians/Orphanage coordinators). NRS 5000 each. Total cost ~$1,000.

NEPAL'S TRAGEDY 2015 IN FIGURES 

Two major Earthquakes, 7.9 and 7.3 Magnitudes, followed by hundreds of aftershocks rocked Central Nepal in April and May 2015, taking lives of more than 8,500 people and injuring over 20,000 people. Authorities say that the hardest hit areas of Sindhupalchowk, Dolakha, Gorkha, Rasuwa, Nuwakot, Dhading and Kathmandu districts might take years to recover.

According to the Ministry of Home Affairs, more than 400,000 houses are damaged or destructed and over 8 Million people have been directly affected. 

Thousands of children have been orphaned by this terrible Earthquake and scores have been disabled. UNICEF reports that more than 5,000 schools have been damaged or destroyed and over 1 Million students are without classrooms. More reports and data are yet to come.UNICEF facts about NepalQuake 2015

Nepalese friends in Netherlands have prepared this video to show how Nepal looked before the Earthquake and what it looks in its aftermath. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oklS38fD59A 

PLEA FOR YOUR HELP

Girl Scout group of Duchesne Academy of the Sacred Heart, Houston Texas, learned about Volunteerism from Dr. Suraj Bhattarai. This year, their 'Scout Action Project' includes 'Earthquakes in Nepal'. For this, girls have been raising funds and collecting relief materials to support underprivileged children in Nepal.

We hope you will join our campaign to uplift the lives of underprivileged and unfortunate children in Nepal. Only with your valuable support, there can be an immediate and sustainable impact. 

Rotary Club of Houston President 2015/16 Mr. Richard Slemaker & other Rotarians supporting our campaign

Let's help Nepal and serve the humanity. 

Thank you, everyone!

Our campaign has been matched with $1,500 to be raised by Interact clubs of Katy. We have sponsored education, living cost, food and clothing for two kids in Sindhupalchowk district, who are now studying in Jugal Boarding School in Grade 6. We hope to continue this project until these children graduate from High school to be able to apply for vocational training, higher education, and jobs. We expect continuous support from you all. Thank you all again. - Suraj Bhattarai, Chris Gibson and Rotary Katy/Rotaract WH Katy familySTORIES FROM THE GROUND"During our Earthquake relief mission in Thulosirubari VDC, Sindhupalchowk, we met these 2 children, raised by their father after they lost their mother nearly a decade ago. Unfortunately, their father also lost his life in the recent Earthquake making their life a series of misery. They are now been taken care by their uncle who is financial weak and already has 6 children of his own. They have no shelter either." Dr. Prabhat Sapkota, one of our local partners from B.P. Koirala Institute of Health Sciences Nepal and a medical doctor involved in the relief mission, shared his experiences from Sindhupalchowk, the district with more than 4,000 deaths.  We would like to disburse a part of our fund for the rehabilitation of these 2 children.Ramita Rokka, 12, and Anil Rokka, 10, from Thulosirubari, Sindhupalchowk district, have been orphaned by the Earthquake. Photo courtesy: Dr. Prabhat Sapkota This story is just one of the thousand other stories which represent children's vulnerability brought about by the Earthquake. According to the Secretary of the Village Development Committee (VDC) and In-charge of the Health post, there are about 20 such children in the village.WHAT WE'RE GOING TO DO West Houston/Katy Rotaract Club members expressing solidarity to Nepal ProjectYoung professionals from Houston, Texas, are very concerned about this natural disaster in Nepal. Representing the Rotary clubs, Rotaract clubs and several other social organizations of Houston, we would like to contribute to the rehabilitation process of disaster victims.Our goal is to provide scholarships, educational materials, medical supplies, immunization and psychosocial counseling for at least 10 children who have been orphaned by this Earthquake. Our additional goal is to reach out to at least 10 households in Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha districts to help rehabilitate Earthquake disabled children. Suraj is returning to Nepal to work on the ground from late June 2015, whereas a team of at least 3 other volunteers from USA led by Chris Gibson, are going to Nepal in Winter to teach and support the underprivileged children.Disbursement of Fund (Beneficiaries: 20 Orphans/Disabled Children)

Elementary to High School Level Books. 3 books to each child. Minimum NRS 600 per child. Total cost ~$150.  


Backpack, Notebooks, Pen and other stationery.  Minimum NRS 1000 per child. Total cost ~$250. 


School Admission fees for 20 children. Minimum NRS 2000 per child. Total cost ~$400. (If we surpass our goal, it can be extended to more children) 

One-year Scholarship for 20 children. Minimum NRS 200 per month per child. Total cost ~$500.(If goal is surpassed, scholarship can be extended to more children)

Medical Bills for Sick/Injured Orphans or Disabled. Minimum NRS 1000 per child. Total cost ~$300. (it depends upon number of sick kids). 

Braces, Sling and Support for Neck/Back/Knees/Foot. Each item can cost up to NPR 500. Total cost ~$200.


Crutches, Wheelchair, Prosthesis or other Orthopedic supplies depending upon the disability of children. Up to NPR 1,500 per item. Total cost ~$600.


Free Immunization (Full doses of Hepatitis B/DPT/MMR/Polio and Vitamin A based on the age) and Deworming prophylaxis with Albendazole. Minimum NPR 1000 per child. Total cost ~$300.

Toothbrush+Toothpaste for 1 year. NRS 300 per child. Total ~$60.

Tampon (Sanitary pad) and Towel. NRS 300 per child. Total ~$60.


Symposium: Psychological Counseling, Motivation lectures, Yoga classes and Adolescent Health Education. Logistic management cost minimum NPR 30,000. Total cost ~$350.

Incentives for Caretakers (Guardians/Orphanage coordinators). NRS 5000 each. Total cost ~$1,000.


NEPAL'S TRAGEDY 2015 IN FIGURES Two major Earthquakes, 7.9 and 7.3 Magnitudes, followed by hundreds of aftershocks rocked Central Nepal in April and May 2015, taking lives of more than 8,500 people and injuring over 20,000 people. Authorities say that the hardest hit areas of Sindhupalchowk, Dolakha, Gorkha, Rasuwa, Nuwakot, Dhading and Kathmandu districts might take years to recover.According to the Ministry of Home Affairs, more than 400,000 houses are damaged or destructed and over 8 Million people have been directly affected. Thousands of children have been orphaned by this terrible Earthquake and scores have been disabled. UNICEF reports that more than 5,000 schools have been damaged or destroyed and over 1 Million students are without classrooms. More reports and data are yet to come.UNICEF facts about NepalQuake 2015Nepalese friends in Netherlands have prepared this video to show how Nepal looked before the Earthquake and what it looks in its aftermath. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oklS38fD59A PLEA FOR YOUR HELP

Girl Scout group of Duchesne Academy of the Sacred Heart, Houston Texas, learned about Volunteerism from Dr. Suraj Bhattarai. This year, their 'Scout Action Project' includes 'Earthquakes in Nepal'. For this, girls have been raising funds and collecting relief materials to support underprivileged children in Nepal.
We hope you will join our campaign to uplift the lives of underprivileged and unfortunate children in Nepal. Only with your valuable support, there can be an immediate and sustainable impact. 
Rotary Club of Houston President 2015/16 Mr. Richard Slemaker & other Rotarians supporting our campaign
Let's help Nepal and serve the humanity. 
Thank you, everyone!

story:
I am a high school teacher at a small rural public charter school in Oregon.

Every 2 years I give my students a chance to go on an educational tour of France or Italy for credit. 

The majority of them come from low-income homes. 

I spend a vast majority of my summer planning and executing fundraisers including a fireworks stand, a week long day-camp, family movie nights and this year a renaissance fair. Most of the decorations, materials and equipment I have donated myself. We bought a travel trailer so staying overnight would be more comfortable. We bought a generator so we didn't have to keep nursing the borrowed one along that acted up regularly. We donated our data plan to use for the reader with a hotspot. You get the picture!

This year when offered a 2nd fireworks location I asked the students if they thought we could do it. They all said yes. 

I would like to streamline the point of sale so sales would all be done with a square reader stand and barcode scanner. 

I believe this will result in more sales, more accurate transactions, and the ability to track sales. It would also mean that we could use more volunteers from the school that perhaps would just like to help out for a day.

Currently we have set up a computer (mine) that I hand entered all the barcodes in. Then we borrow the barcode scanner from the school office (used for volunteer hours) and in an Excel document we open Find and Replace and then scan the item. It finds the item they want and then they note the price and type it into the cheap cash register we have. If customers want to pay with a card, we swipe their card with the square reader that is placed either on my cell phone (which I have to leave with them) or theirs. If a call or text comes in in the middle of the sale, it interrupts the sale and further slows the process. I receive many calls for support during the season and end up spending a lot of time at the tent personally.

I am stressed about having to set up a 2nd system like this one that is highly inefficient and prone to error. 

What We Need

*2 Square register stands $99x2=$198

*2 iPads:  iPad 4 with 3G 16GB  $399x2=$798

*Honeywell Voyager 1250G Barcode Scanner $77x2=154

Fees: $50

Total: $1200

The Impact

This purchase will impact my students for years to come. I will be able to have it at all of our fundraisers. It will further teach students how to use the system that they potentially could encounter on a job. Many of my students have put their experiences fundraising with me on their resumes. The iPad's will also be able to be used year round in my classroom. Our PTO will also be able to borrow the POS system and use it at our local auction. 

Risks & Challenges

If I am unable to raise the funds for this project, I will piece together a system like we have currently for the one fireworks tent. It means purchasing another cash register to hold the money and finding another computer and barcode scanner to use plus another hotspot. 
I prefer not to take the funds from the students for this project since they work so very hard to scrape together enough money as it is.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to provide a scholarship for a student or sponsor them for a day, please let me know!

  • Make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
This campaign has been superseded by our sponsorship site....

www.businessbackingveterans.com 


The Opportunity

According to www.ptsd.va.gov 5.2 million servicemen and women suffer from Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and on average, 22 of them commit suicide every single day. In the United States anxiety disorders cost around $42 billion dollars a year, almost a third of the total mental health budget. The most common treatments are psychotherapy and medication, both of which could be for life. 

Today you have the opportunity to help by supporting our project and we are so grateful for your contribution, thank you. 

The PTG Treatment and Educational Program

We intend to treat and educate a minimum of 6 veterans and servicemen and women in six cities (36 total) across the US over a 2 year period, starting in Los Angeles, where we will be based. The focus being on Post Traumatic Growth rather than stress, as words have a relevance in relation to vibrational frequencies, and growth is a positive vibration from the outset.

The program would involve three individual treatments with each of the candidates, over a 21 day period. Then they will receive one weeks full time training, with a 150 hour home study section to be honored over the following 12 months. Candidates will be taught how to carry out treatments that are formulated specifically for treating people suffering from PTSD. The program will involve both theory and practical training and diplomas will be awarded once the case studies have been assessed and approved.

The Candidates

We aim to teach people who have been in combat, as well as those who have not, and here will be no discrimination in relation to age, sex or ethnic background. 

Summary

Crystal Ki healing is a 21st Century phenomenon that has to be experienced to be appreciated; it is extremely powerful and produces amazing results very quickly. This link will give you access to a 5 minute Crystal Ki Healing sample. Please do not listen to this whilst you are driving or operating machinery, and for best results find a quiet space and use headphones.

Crystal Ki Healing Sample Audio – Click Here (It only takes 5 Minutes)

We are now ready to begin this program and are prepared to relocate in September 2015, once we have the funding required. If you would like to help us with funding or private accommodation, or can pass this proposal on to someone who can, we would be extremely grateful. If you have any other questions, please do contact us. Thank you for reading this, we look forward to hearing from you soon.  

"Thank you so much for you donation, we really appreciate your help..."

With Blessings

story:
SAPURA'S STORY

Hi, my name is Surya Shahi, I was born in Humla, Nepal in 1995, and thanks to much generosity I had the opportunity to come to the United States to attend College as an International Student. My story has inspired many, unfortunately, it is not reflective of the larger student population in my native country---where even the most capable student is shut out of education. 

The earthquake that struck in April was devastating for every family across Nepal, thousands of lives were lost and our country sunk deeper as one of the poorest countries in the world, especially the district that I grew up in, Humla, which is now the poorest district in Nepal. There are no roads, transportation or electricity and my family and neighbors still struggle to find jobs, health services and of course, access to education.

I was blessed enough to escape this tough reality that many of my friends and family members still face because I was given an opportunity to pursue my education in international schools and now university in America because of my godparents who have supported me since I was five. Nevertheless, to me, it is heartbreaking that not all children can be as lucky as I am.

Someone I love dearly still struggles to find access to higher education, my sister Sapura Shahi. Through much sacrifice and support from my family, she recently passed her SLC (School Leaving Certificate,) she scored a B. Her work is all the more notable to me and my parents as for someone from a poor and disregarded district as Humla is, to pass the SLC is a huge accomplishment. I immediately expressed the joy for her when I heard the news. I was beyond happy and excited that she would be able to attend college, beating all odds by being the only girl from our village to make such stride.

Unfortunately, not all was good news; a week later I got a phone call from my parents who explained how they were unable to pay for my sister’s education. In my village, this would not be out of the normal, the circumstances and lack of money pressure young girls to forgo their chance at an education—forced to marry at a young age. The truth is that most will end up working in the fields, herding cattle, collecting firewood, cooking and performing an endless list of chores, daily.

I do not want all of my sister’s hard-work to be thrown away, it would devastate me to see her potential be wasted. Sapura dreams of continuing her education to become a nurse, she shares with me hopes of one day being able to help others. She is asking for a chance at a better life and I promised my sister that she will go to school and her dreams and hopes will become a reality

Research shows that increased access to education for girls equals progress on reducing gender-based violence, early marriage, and other harmful practices---furthermore, education increases participation by women and girls in their community, decision making and makes for a happier and more fulfilling life.

Education can change the lives of people for good, especially the lives of young girls like my sister. I do believe that helping my sister obtain an education will send a strong statement to others and will create rippling effects, encouraging many to continue their education.

I promised my sister that I would help her realize her dream of an education and I can only do that with your help. Your donation will change my sister’s life and the lives of many around her. Please help me fulfill this promise by donating, together we can make my sister’s dream a reality.


The Impact

Sapura wants to become a nurse with the clear goal of coming back to her village to help the injured and provide basic health training for others. Especially after the earthquake, basic needs became even more difficult to fulfill and people are dying as result of small infections because there is no immediate treatment provided. The village of Karanga is in a remote zone in the top of the mountains and the closest health center is located seven hours away, as result of that many die waiting for medical attention. 

Sapura has always had the passion of helping others and she feels deeply about helping her village overcome otherwise small infections from taking lives. 

#Onenurse in the village would drastically improve the lives of many. 


How the money will be used

100% of your donation will go to support Sapura during the entire program she needs to become a nurse.


TUITION $7,000

TRAVELING $1,500

FOOD $1,500

ROOM $1,000


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone has different giving abilities. If you are unable to make a monetary contribution, you can help us out by sharing news and updates about our campaign on facebook, twitter, tumblr, email, and word-of-mouth with people you know: your friends, family, coworkers, religious leaders, teachers, and fellow students.

Together we can build a movement TALK ABOUT IT - TWEET ABOUT IT - INSTAGRAM AND FACEBOOK ABOUT IT! 


Use this hashtags when sharing: 


#SAPURADREAM #ONENURSE



PLEASE DONATE & SHARE WIDELY.

story:
a letter from the founders

----------

Dear Friend

What can 100 kids build for themselves using just a wall and their free spirit? Hope. We walk up to all kinds of places in India to work with vulnerable children and help them build a hypercool library of their own using just a wall - and so we call this a Wall O Books. We equip it with a startup stash of 100 books (and a world map, a light bulb and a few more things :) and elect a little librarian to take care of it. 

And then we take one child and connect her to another child in another part of the country using just a postcard, magically.

But before we tell you the rest of our story let us tell you what we need from you. We have built 26 Wall O Books so far. We want to build 1000 this year. We can build 100 on our own. We need your help to build the other 900. 

Thank You
Swastika & Sanjukt

Saina's story

----------

One ordinary day, somewhere in India, we walked up to a school for vulnerable children and wondered - what is it like growing up within these dark and grey walls? We met Saina, an eight year old, and asked her what does she want to be when she grows up. 

I want to be a police officer. Criminals who commit crime, and crime is growing so fast in our world - those criminals, I want to catch them. 

Saina wants to fly.
But first we need to open a window for her to the world outside. 

Our children are growing up in a narrow world. Where hope is not even a four letter word. School is a window. Or is it just a door? For our children continue to stay only in the world next door. We wondered how we could change all of that.

Books. Because in spite of everything that can go wrong and stay wrong around them, books can transcend all that, protect them and help them grow. 

For each of the 100 children covered by a Wall O Books Center, the books they receive are often their first view of the world outside. 

And so we take a wall, put a simple, cool and innovative bookshelf made out of an empty gunny bag on it, and start off a tiny, big library with 100 books for 100 children.

The kids build this entirely with their own hands. They even elect a li’l librarian getting their first brush with democracy :) There are no restrictions to when and how many books they can read. They can carry the books home. The little librarian ensures that no book gets lost :)

Saina is now the elected librarian of her Wall O Books. Will you spare 7 minutes to step into her world and listen to her acceptance speech?

And then we take Saina and connect her to another child in another part of the country using just a postcard, magically.

----------

We want to help each child develop and share a sense of identity, hope, friendship and knowledge with another child in another part of the country. 


a million little dreams

----------

We have worked with over 2400 children across 7 states, 10 cities and 35 different institutions for vulnerable children. We want to expand this project to all the 29 states in India – 100 Wall O Books in each state, each covering a minimum of 100 children, in total covering 290,000 children - all of them using the books to learn and using the postcards to share and gain new perspective from each other.

meet our team

----------

Quick question. If it takes 2 days to build one Wall O Books, how many days would it take to build 100? 200 days? 50 days? We got you! 

It takes just 2 days. What it takes is also a team that can get this figured. Well, it took us about three months to figure that out! We are a hybrid Not For Profit Foundation with a strong full time team. Men and women. Engineers and MBAs. Young and Old. Indians. And even a Canadian. Breaking some walls out of the joyous city of Calcutta in India. Come join us ...


How you can help?

----------

Thank you for reading our story so far. 

As we wrote right in the beginning, we need your help to build 900 out of our target of 1000 Wall O Books this year. We have built 26 so far and we can build 100 on our own. We are on a mission to build a total of 2900 Wall O Books in India, 100 in each state, covering a total of 290,000 children in the next three years.

We are looking for contributions in four categories - $5 helps to buy a book and hundred smiles, $25 helps create a Pocket O Books with 5 - 12 books inside, $125 creates a full Wall O Books with 9 pockets and 100 books and finally, $500 helps to run it for a full year. 

We have kept our best perk for a $5 contribution. 

If you choose to do this, you will receive the complete Wall O Books Design Kit so that you can build your own Wall O Books for vulnerable children in your city. We will guide you through the process and extend to you our relationships with publishers who love us and give us special discounts for books. 

We have kept it this way so that we can trigger a large and open movement around our idea to build a simple, hyper-cool library of 100 books for children around the world.

Let your friends know for all we need is $5 to make it happen.

----------

You can call Swastika +91 97350.16096 and Sanjukt +91 97485.30105 to talk and tell us how we can do it better. Visit our world on facebook.com/wallobooks and twitter.com/wallobooks as well as wallobooks.org
story_txt:
a letter from the founders----------Dear FriendWhat can 100 kids build for themselves using just a wall and their free spirit? Hope. We walk up to all kinds of places in India to work with vulnerable children and help them build a hypercool library of their own using just a wall - and so we call this a Wall O Books. We equip it with a startup stash of 100 books (and a world map, a light bulb and a few more things :) and elect a little librarian to take care of it. And then we take one child and connect her to another child in another part of the country using just a postcard, magically.But before we tell you the rest of our story let us tell you what we need from you. We have built 26 Wall O Books so far. We want to build 1000 this year. We can build 100 on our own. We need your help to build the other 900. Thank YouSwastika & Sanjukt
Saina's story
----------One ordinary day, somewhere in India, we walked up to a school for vulnerable children and wondered - what is it like growing up within these dark and grey walls? We met Saina, an eight year old, and asked her what does she want to be when she grows up. I want to be a police officer. Criminals who commit crime, and crime is growing so fast in our world - those criminals, I want to catch them. Saina wants to fly. But first we need to open a window for her to the world outside. Our children are growing up in a narrow world. Where hope is not even a four letter word. School is a window. Or is it just a door? For our children continue to stay only in the world next door. We wondered how we could change all of that.Books. Because in spite of everything that can go wrong and stay wrong around them, books can transcend all that, protect them and help them grow. For each of the 100 children covered by a Wall O Books Center, the books they receive are often their first view of the world outside. And so we take a wall, put a simple, cool and innovative bookshelf made out of an empty gunny bag on it, and start off a tiny, big library with 100 books for 100 children.The kids build this entirely with their own hands. They even elect a li’l librarian getting their first brush with democracy :) There are no restrictions to when and how many books they can read. They can carry the books home. The little librarian ensures that no book gets lost :)Saina is now the elected librarian of her Wall O Books. Will you spare 7 minutes to step into her world and listen to her acceptance speech?
And then we take Saina and connect her to another child in another part of the country using just a postcard, magically.


----------
We want to help each child develop and share a sense of identity, hope, friendship and knowledge with another child in another part of the country. 

a million little dreams
----------
We have worked with over 2400 children across 7 states, 10 cities and 35 different institutions for vulnerable children. We want to expand this project to all the 29 states in India – 100 Wall O Books in each state, each covering a minimum of 100 children, in total covering 290,000 children - all of them using the books to learn and using the postcards to share and gain new perspective from each other.

meet our team
----------
Quick question. If it takes 2 days to build one Wall O Books, how many days would it take to build 100? 200 days? 50 days? We got you! 



It takes just 2 days. What it takes is also a team that can get this figured. Well, it took us about three months to figure that out! We are a hybrid Not For Profit Foundation with a strong full time team. Men and women. Engineers and MBAs. Young and Old. Indians. And even a Canadian. Breaking some walls out of the joyous city of Calcutta in India. Come join us ...




How you can help?
----------
Thank you for reading our story so far. As we wrote right in the beginning, we need your help to build 900 out of our target of 1000 Wall O Books this year. We have built 26 so far and we can build 100 on our own. We are on a mission to build a total of 2900 Wall O Books in India, 100 in each state, covering a total of 290,000 children in the next three years.
We are looking for contributions in four categories - $5 helps to buy a book and hundred smiles, $25 helps create a Pocket O Books with 5 - 12 books inside, $125 creates a full Wall O Books with 9 pockets and 100 books and finally, $500 helps to run it for a full year. 
We have kept our best perk for a $5 contribution. 
If you choose to do this, you will receive the complete Wall O Books Design Kit so that you can build your own Wall O Books for vulnerable children in your city. We will guide you through the process and extend to you our relationships with publishers who love us and give us special discounts for books. 
We have kept it this way so that we can trigger a large and open movement around our idea to build a simple, hyper-cool library of 100 books for children around the world.
Let your friends know for all we need is $5 to make it happen.
----------
You can call Swastika +91 97350.16096 and Sanjukt +91 97485.30105 to talk and tell us how we can do it better. Visit our world on facebook.com/wallobooks and twitter.com/wallobooks as well as wallobooks.org

story:
HELLO SUPPORTERS & VISIONARIES!

ABOUT -- 

TERRA BABEL is 501c3 Approved Non Profit initiative that engages indigenous communities, the world's oldest remaining cultures in danger of extinction, to participate in the process of their own preservation, giving them a VOICE  though Creative Expression in the universal language of Art & Photography. 

My name is Paul L. R. Du Bois and I am the founder of the L. R. Du Bois Foundation and creator for the TERRA BABEL PROJECT. This project will benefit not only the people in ancient communities in our world, who are in desperate need of assistance, but all of us for generations to come. 

As a Creative Director I was privileged to work with award-winning international agencies, and as Artist & Explorer, the gift to journey across borders and explore the magic we, as a people, express in the form of our imagination.  

It is through our collective limitless imagination that I invite you to take a journey that is going to change our world : 

I would like you to ask yourselves one simple question --

"If you were the last of your People, what would your Legacy be? "

WHY THESE CULTURES NEEED YOUR HELP -- 

The oldest remaining cultures in our planet are suffering nothing short than cultural genocide, affecting all of humanity, due to unregulated progress. 

The fact that the majority of the people in our world are unaware of the existence of these ancient peoples and their cultural realities, make them vulnerable. 

This recklesness opens the door to abuse through human rights violations, much of which is unaddressed by the world today. 

Families, children and whole communities are often displaced from their ancestral homes, their way of life destroyed, and their history | our history | exterminated in the process.



THE LAUCH OF THE PROJECT--

ARTISTS & CULTURES UNITE TO CREATE A NEW VISUAL LANGUAGE, GIVING A VOICE TO THOSE THAT HAVE NONE, AS THEY SHOW US NEW WORLDS.

For our launch, we will journey to TWO of the world's oldest cultures in danger of extinction :

MAORI of New Zealand & Q'ERO Shamans of Peru. 

Art works will be created by the members of the disappearing indigenous communities, together with a team made of impactful artists, showing us their VOICE in the form of various of Artistic Platforms, portraying their incredible unseen CREATIVITY,  which will show the world the cultural & social challenges they face, as well as the beauty of the origins -- humanity's cultural heritage.

example of visual expression created by aboriginal artist | Australia | the Anangu Pitjantjatjara

THE POWER & IMPACT OF THE FREEDOM OF VISUAL SPEECH TRANSCENDS CULTURES --

INDIGENOUS CULTURES & THEIR PEOPLES WILL RECEIVE INTERNATIONAL AWARENESS, AS THEY PROVIDE AN INVALUABLE CULTURAL CONTRIBUTION + GIFT TO OUR WORLD THROUGH THE UNIQUE VOICE OF THEIR CREATIVE EXPRESSION.


THE MAGNITUDE OF YOUR TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION -- 

Your invaluable support, will enable --

1-- JOURNEY : (i) Cover travel cost, (ii) Cover materials needed for Cultural Art Creation (iii) Development of final product which will...

2 -- EXHIBITION : connect the art works through int'l galleries and museums, allowing us to discover their realities, challenges, and beauty of their lives, giving these incredible people a place in our word.  

3-- EDUCATION : Help us create the Terra Babel Cultural Educational E-Books, Free to the public and easily downloadable online. The e-books, we will showcase the stories of these incredible culture's origins, the people within each tribe, and the art they create told by the culture itself. 

OUR WORLD WILL LEARN AND DISCOVER THE MAGIC IT STILL CONTAINS, AS IT JOURNEYS WITH US --  

"We Are Fascinated With The Recording Of Life

The Moments Of Our Lives

And Those Around Us

To Fill A Yearning

And Catch A Glimpse Of The Human Spirit

This Pushes Us To See Our World Behind Its Walls

To Discover What Is Now And The Things To Come 

To Draw Closer & Find Each Other

Where We Came From & Where We Are Going

We Do This To Understand

To Feel & To See

To Find Our Meaning

To Reach For The Unknown"™

WE HONOR THESE PRINCIPLES BY ENSURING THE DIVERSITY OF OUR WORLD’S CULTURAL HERITAGES ARE GIVEN A PLACE | A VOICE | THROUGH THE TRANSCENDENT COMMUNICATION PLATFORM KNOWN AS | IMAGE | FREEDOM OF VISUAL SPEECH.™


HOW YOU WILL RECEIVE YOUR TAX DEDUCTIBLE PAPERWORK -- 

YOU WILL RECEIVE AN EMAIL  AUTOMATICALLY  WITH YOUR TAX DEDUCTIBLE RECEIPT :) We are a Verified Nonprofit so when you contribute, you will receive an email from Firstgiving confirming the tax-deductible status of your contribution. For more information click HERE 

If you require an additional tax receipt, you can also reach out to us directly : hello@lrduboisfoundation.org.


THANK YOU FOR YOUR VALUABLE CONTRIBUTION :)

story:
Why Robotics

The ability to write computer programs and build robots is an important part of literacy in today’s society. Young people learn strategies for solving problems, designing projects and communicating ideas in the process of carrying out a robotics project.

Robotics is a fascinating way to help kids learn to think creatively, reason systematically and work collaboratively. In the future, not knowing the language of computers will be as challenging as being an illiterate today.

Will every job in the future involve programming? No. But it is still crucial that every child learns to code.

This is not primarily about equipping the next generation to work as robotics engineers; it is about promoting computational thinking. Computational thinking is how software engineers solve problems. It combines mathematics, logic and algorithms, and teaches kids a new way to think about the world.

Why Nigeria?

Nigeria is blessed with a huge youthful population. Over 60% of the 170 million Nigerians are under the age of 35. The major criterion for a great future for the country is sound education for its kids and youths.

Today, high school education in Nigeria is more about memorizing of academic materials to pass exams. The goal of most school owners is to make students pass WASSCE (West African Secondary School Certificate Examinations) in flying colours. You can’t create innovators and problems solvers that way.

As important and brilliant as robotics and coding is to the education of our kids. It is still an out-of-the-world thing in Nigeria.

Less than 1% of high schools in Nigeria teach coding or robotics. Most school principals don’t even know what coding/robotics is.

Our intention is to champion the beginning of a great paradigm in the Nigerian education system. We want to expose our young students to real-world engineering challenges through hands-on LEGO-based robotics projects. We want Nigerian kids to begin to think creatively and innovate like their international counterparts. 


Why now?

The Nigerian educational system has been neglected for so many years. The country has a huge population of unchallenged youths. If we don’t fix it NOW, then WHEN?

This project is scheduled to start in September 2015 through April 2016.

How many schools?

200 secondary schools across 6 Nigerian cities: Lagos, Ibadan, Osogbo, Akure, Ile-Ife, Abeokuta. Presently, we have invited 53 schools to be part of the project. The remaining 147 schools will be invited in September 2015.

As part of the project, we would be training 80 girls at the Women’s Technology Empowerment Center (W-TEC), Yaba Lagos, 50 kids at Kids and Teens Resource Center, Akure, and 100 kids at 2 orphanages in Lagos.

How many kids per school?

We are training 50 kids per secondary school. Kids between ages 10 and 14.

How many instructors are we using per school?

4 ACI robotics instructors per school. 


How many instructors in all?

We would be using about 800 instructors for the whole project. Presently we have 200 instructors on ground. Among them are former FirstStep BootCamp students in Obafemi Awolowo University and University of Ibadan, and undergraduate robotics engineers at iLab, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, who have represented Nigeria in the World Robotics Olympiad (WRO) in Indonesia. We intend to train more instructors during the course of the project.

How long per school?

Our robotics instructors would visit each school 4 times. Each class (visit) would be for 3 hours.


How are we going to spend the money?

We are training 10,000 Nigerian kids in robotics. Intensive classes! This is a huge project. Every dollar contributed would be going into quite a number of things:

1.  LEGO Robotics Kit:

We want every 6 students we train to have a FULL robotics kit to themselves during the program.

2.  Transportation:

Our undergraduate instructors would be transported to schools in Ibadan, Lagos, Abeokuta, Ife, Akure and Osogbo from Obafemi Awolowo University, Ife and University of Ibadan campuses on a daily basis. That is 32 instructors daily (see the illustrations above).

3.  T-shirts for students and instructors:

We would be giving each of the 10,000 kids a i-can-build-a-robot T-shirt each. From experience, kids love the T-shirt.

4.  Lunch allowance for the instructors:

All our 800 undergraduate instructors would be taking part in the project on a volunteering basis. We are not paying them. A snack and drink won’t be a bad idea!

5.  Logistics



#Project10000kids is a very huge program that will have a lasting impact in the Nigerian education system. This is because it will be taking place in 6 major cities (in 5 states) in South-western Nigerian. This would surely have a ripple effect across the country.

The termly robotics competition (starting from December 2015) would ensure continuous robotics research and learning within the schools. The students that would take part in this project would in a way influence and pass on the knowledge to their mates at school.

For the first time in a country of over 170 million people, robotics would be taught in average and below average Nigerian high schools for FREE.

With our partnership with iLab, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, National Instruments and Enactus International we believe we can make this a huge success in Nigeria.

Project10000kids is a big project and would definitely come with a number of risks. The one that readily comes to mind is the fact that we would be working with 200 schools in 6 different cities, any of the schools might disrupt our ready-made schedule by postponing one of the classes due to some circumstances/events peculiar to the school. Apart from this, there could be any other unforeseen situation that could hinder a particular day’s class from holding. We had this in mind when we said the project would run from September 2015 through April 2016. In actual fact, classes would be holding in October 2015, November 2015, January 2016, February 2016 and in March 2016. Secondary schools in Nigeria would be having their school examinations in December 2015 and we have the month of April 2016 as a “backup” month in case of any alteration in our timetable due the above challenges.

Another important issue that needs to be considered is the availability of instructors. As a matter of fact, all we need are 160 instructors (The diagrams above explain that in a brilliant way). That means we have to reuse the instructors each month. But that is not realistic. A very large percentage of our instructors are undergraduates at Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife and University of Ibadan. These guys would be busy with academic work at school, so a month (4 days within that month) is just okay for each of them. And new set of guys takes over in a new month. That way, we would be using 800 guys in all and it would be rare for us to lack an instructor. Just as we have mentioned previously, we have 200 robotics instructors presently. The other 600 would be trained once we get our funding.

                                                

Check the right hand side of the your screen, you will see the wonderful perks we have for you. The illustration below is for the $25, $100, $500, $1000 and $2500 perks. Your name would be printed on one of the kids' t-shirt. It would look like this:





You can help in so so many other ways. Everything is not about money!

You can like our Page on Facebook and share this project on Facebook.

Tweet about this project using #Project10000Kids.

Follow us on Instagram and gist your friends and family about this awesome project. 

Send the coordinator an email if you want to be part of the project in some other ways: olaoluwaaci@gmail.com 

A great number of Nigerian kids would have a brighter future as a result of the project. All thanks to you. We love you.

story:
This campaign is a follow up on Thom Feeney’s Greek Bailout Fund, organized by a Volunteering student Group from Athens with the sole purpose of seeing our country back to its former self!

We would like to start off by thanking Thom Feeney for making this possible, and everyone who donated even one cent we have to thank from the bottom of our hearts!

When we read the comments on Thom Feeney’s Greek Bailout Fund campaign, allot of comments where saying that the campaign should change it’s funding type from Fixed to a Flexible Funding one and that the money should go to the Greek people, we were simply astonished (over 100.000 people in just 7 days!) and at the same time inspired on how much everyone wanted to help us! After that we decided to make a new campaign which will not be fixed funding.

Fixed funding (meaning that if the required goal of 1.6 billion is not reached in time  then it gets refunded in full), and it has not achieved even 5% of that. (It got refunded by now), hopefully we can make it and help the people as they deserve!

The donations acquired in this campaign will go to:

50% will go to the National Pension Fund (IKA) which is empty and this month allot (up to 25% of pensions where not paid due to “paper problems, but we all know why”) (Once money is there it cant be spent anywhere else, it will be a donation from the People around the globe represented by this campaign)

50% will go into donating to local charity organizations that have been giving out food, clothing and medicine for free for the donated money (such as Stasi Zois, Children’s Village, Volunteer Work Athens, Kivotos,  ActionAid Hellas, Unicef Committee Hellas, Nea Zoi  – All of which are non-profit organizations that actually help people).

*All those that donated on the previous campaign we thank you so much for doing it in the first place! If you can however extend your support and donate again!

Some estimates:
According to data submitted to the Greek Parliament by the Public Debt Management Agency (ODDHX), the Debt of the Public Administration on 30 April 2015 was: 312,679,022,950 euro.

So safe to say that without a money flow Inside the people (unless the money is going to bankers, IMF, ECB, unelected bureaucrats of the European Commission directly) the economy won’t rise up without at least some help from somewhere, and this is somewhere. For many years now we have been forced to not just work over-hours, but at Europe’s lowest average annual salary.

*One of the team members is a representative of Stasi Zois charity in Greece - http://www.stasizois.org/

For those who really want to make a donation to Greece, don’t repay their debt, but help them directly by donating to this charity, and it will be distributed directly to the Greek People, my people.

student Group from Athens with the sole purpose of seeing our country back to
its former self!We would like to start off by thanking Thom Feeney for making this possible, and everyone who donated even one cent we have to thank from the bottom of our hearts!
When we
read the comments on Thom Feeney’s Greek Bailout Fund campaign, allot of comments where saying that the
campaign should change it’s funding type from Fixed to a Flexible Funding one and that
the money should go to the Greek people, we were simply astonished (over
100.000 people in just 7 days!) and at the same time inspired on how much
everyone wanted to help us! After that we decided to make a new campaign which will not
be fixed funding.

story:
Who is GIBRON or Qui Etes-Vous M. Shepperd?

Hello, my name is Gibron Shepperd and GIBRON is my namesake lifestyle-clothing brand.  The line is about paradoxes; an aesthetic I call bourgeois bohemian.  A design world that is one part glossy, sophisticated, artifice and one part honesty and nature.

I was born with an affinity for fabrics and composing a story through them.  As a young child I wanted to be an artist, often finding myself drawing women in clothes and making accessories like origami earrings and bags out of paper.  All through middle school and high school, I created small businesses from baked goods to apothecary.  By the end of high school I decided I wanted to dedicate myself wholly to fashion design. I studied fashion design and small business management at West Valley College in Northern California for two years.  Everyday since graduating high school, I have dreamed of this brand, and it’s finally time to make it a reality!



What We Do & What You Get

With your help I hope to raise $75,000, a very small amount for a multi-category start up fashion brand.  In addition to the GIBRON clothing line, within the first year we plan to have home fragrances, a line of natural beauty products, and leather goods.  Having multiple categories allows clients to access facets of GIBRON through various price points: meaning that individuals that cant afford the $750 coat can still have a piece of the brand by purchasing a $10 lip butter.

Nearly 50% of funding will go to fabrics and supplies, 25% will go to business fees, marketing, and miscellaneous expenses like models and studio upkeep and the last 25% is a year’s stipend.  If you have questions on the specifics of my business plan or budget, feel free to contact me. 

Once funds have amassed, production will begin!  We will start with a small holiday collection that will be presented at Renegade Craft Fair.  A spring collection and the beginning of a basics line, from which customers can always order classic pieces, will follow this. 

For your gracious donations you will receive the perks listed on the side of the screen.


Your Impact on Us

The greatest challenge with the development of Gibron has been the lack of time I could devote to the production due to my fulltime job and lack of discretionary income. Even with minimal financial capital and time that I had available, I have created and developed two collections that include custom prints, leather goods and home decor.  If I can reach the goal of $75,000 it would allow me to dedicate all my time to building the brand to its full potential. 

Risks & Challenges

This is my biggest business venture and with that may come unprecedented issues, however I’m very excited to take them on headfirst.  The greatest problem the brand currently faces is low visibility, but this will be remedied by aligning GIBRON with like-minded craft and trade shows.  I have a long history of working in retail and customer service, which have helped me refine my salesmanship skills.  GIBRON is operating on a lean business model, which means the client’s reaction to products can be implemented very quickly, making the line more and more appealing to the target market.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute monetarily there are other ways to help out!  Spread the word to anyone and everyone, follow us on Instagram, Facebook, Tumblr and head over to GIBRON.com to sign up for our newsletter 'Memorandum'.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Amanda Miller and I am a graduate of the New York CAPP program, a 6 month Certification in Applied Positive Psychology offered by The Flourishing Center.  This program has made such a profound impact on my life and the lives of my peers that we have joined together to create the CAPP Alumni Association. We are running this campaign to give people who are passionate about making a positive impact in the world, that may not otherwise have the financial means to make their full tuition, an opportunity to participate in CAPP. 

The CAPP Alumni Association is a network of CAPP graduates that are dedicated to continuing to grow and deepen the community that they’ve created in CAPP. We aim to unite CAPP graduates across multiple cohorts for networking, collaborating, continuing education and mutual support. The CAPP Alumni Association is bonded by a deep desire to build their wellbeing and the wellbeing of those around them, and a deep appreciation for the gifts that the CAPP program and the Flourishing Center has given them. 

In CAPP we learn about SoMo Leaders (Social and Emotional Leaders).  These are people who understand that they do not live in a bubble.  That the changes they make within themselves ripple out to the their networks of friends, family, co-workers and community at large.

SoMo Leaders see themselves as change agents and catalysts for positivity in their community. They understand deeply the ties that connect all beings and focus on being the change they wish to see in the world. 


Given the opportunity to be involved in the CAPP program, SoMo Leaders will amplify their impact by getting more tools and resources for how to empower people to thrive. It is these inspirational people that the CAPP Alumni Association looks to aid on their path towards flourishing through this scholarship opportunity. 

The CAPP Alumni Association has its own scholarship committee that reviews applications for the potential beneficiaries and provides scholarship opportunities for passionate leaders who demonstrate financial need.

As a twenty-year old college student, living away from home, the CAPP family stepped in and became my family away from home. The emotional support along with the benefit of learning positive psychology tools were priceless.  And, being surrounded by warm, resilient, and confident leaders was an experience that cannot be replicated elsewhere. I believe that everybody should have the opportunity to be a part of such a loving and empowering community.  I am one of many people whose life has been positively impacted, click here to hear more from other CAPP graduates.  Thank you so much for your interest in helping us meet our mission of helping spread positive psychology and CAPP throughout the world.

What We Need

Our goal is to raise one half scholarship for each of the 7 CAPP Cohorts that will be starting in New York City, Philadelphia, Boston, Chicago, Washington D.C., San Francisco and Toronto this Fall. A total of $15,750 will give 7 people the opportunity to participate in the CAPP Program and take what they learn back to their community.  

If we do not reach our goal of $15,750, we will distribute the funds evenly amongst the seven locations. If we exceed our goal, we will divide the excess funds to our students and provide them with even more assistance!

Every little bit makes an impact! Thank you for your support!

The Impact

Not only does your donation help a potential CAPP student get to learn these tools and transform their lives, your contribution ripples out exponentially.  In CAPP we explore the research that shows how impact spreads within social networks with as much as 3 degrees of influence.  When you help a potential CAPP student, they go on to help hundreds of others, who then connect with hundreds more.  

One of the incredible things that The Flourishing Center does is that they track the wellbeing of the CAPP Students pre and post CAPP. Then annually, The Flourishing Center, as a registered Benefit Corporation (BCorp) in the State of New York, publishes the Flourishing Impact Report on how their work has been of benefit to the planet.  

As a contributor, you will be sent a copy of The Flourishing Impact Report because you would have been a part of the impact that is spreading. 

Positive psychology is a rapidly growing field because it provides individuals, organizations and communities with scientifically proven tools for flourishing. While the field is expanding it is up to us change agents to spread these resources. The world needs more social and emotional leaders (SoMo leaders) to introduce wellbeing across all elements of life- relationships, career, vitality, and more! Thank you for being a SoMo leader in your desire to help our students. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are passionate about this fundraiser, but can't contribute, it doesn't mean you can't help! We would love your help in spreading this campaign and getting the word out! Indiegogo provides sharing tools to reach family and friends. People might ask, "What is CAPP?" or "What is Positive Psychology?" Refer them to our website, www.certificateinpositivepsychology.com. There are lots of resources on the site from free live events to inspirational stories of positive psychology in action.

Thank you for reading!

Yours in Flourishing,

Amanda Miller, CAPP

story:
Hello!

My name is Raul Roa and I'm a photojournalist in Southern California. I'm also an avid bird photographer and bird watcher.   I've given birdwatching presentations at my son's elementary school and children loved them.  Birdwatching takes people outdoors and people exercise without even realizing it.  One can spend half an hour to a couple of hours in no time looking for birds at a local park or even just around the neighborhood.  So, with children's obesity rate at an all time high, I want to help children get outdoors and I think that I can do my part to get children interested in the outdoors and walking. There are many natural areas and nature centers but many times children and their parents don't even realize how close they are to some of them. I want to introduce children to the nature centers and natural areas so they can spend times outdoors walking and looking for birds.

After giving my birdwatching presentations, children always send me letters expressing their admiration and awe for the birds I've shown them.  Some of them tell me they went home and looked for birds, or went to the zoo and looked at exotic birds.  One child once told me, when I was wrapping up my slide show, that he wished he could go home with me because he liked the birds I showed him so much! Children sometimes just need a little bit of a push to get outdoors and walk.

Birding is a great activity that gives everyone some exercise.  Spending a half an hour to a few hours outdoors can be good for anyone, including children. I plan to give a slideshow of birds 3rd and 4th grade students can see all around them and then take them on a short birding walk around their school grounds. I need binoculars, bird books, and equipment to give the slide show and show them how to take a photo or two of the birds they see, plus materials for them to keep that they can use later as they birdwatch themselves.  It's a huge project but I am confident that I can accomplish it. I do not plan to charge the schools for my time and service.

I want to do it on a volunteer basis but I need your help to achieve this goal.  I need the right equipment to give them a presentation and birding walk that will get spark their interest in the outdoors.   I plan to start these events in the Fall and do them for a couple of hours, a few times per month or more, on my days off. The school's won't have to pay for the presentations. 

Here are some quotes from children who have seen my presentation.

“You taught us about birds. I got inspired so I set up a bird feeder in my backyard.”

Yolanda, 3rd grade student

“Thank you for showing us the birds and teaching us different kinds of birds, what they eat and their habitat.”

Andre, 3rd grade student

“I wish you can visit us again.”

Henry, 3rd grade student

“Thank you for all the pictures you showed our class.  By the way, never stop looking at birds.”

Jessica, 3rd grade student

“I wish I was like you.  I can’t wait to see a Condor.”

Jordan, 3rd grade student

And a teacher's note.

“Once again you’ve enlightened my students… Hopefully the increased awareness will encourage them to take care of our earth.”

3rd grade teacher

I also do two birding walks a year, as a volunteer, for the city of Glendale Parks & Rec. and maybe I can also do these at community centers for larger groups of children as well. I have friends in various cities parks & rec depts. and I know they'd be thrilled to have me show kids how to bird. I realize that our economy has hit everyone hard, but I also know that there are those people out there, like many of you, who are able to help.  So, I humbly and respectfully ask you to help me help children. Please go to the website and donate whatever you can and please share the link with others who can help as well.  I thank you from the bottom of my heart in advance.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I'm asking for $30,000 for equipment and materials that will serve for many many years. The initial investment is a lot of money but it will buy everything I need to get children involved in birdwatching. I need binoculars and bird books to lend to the entire class at each visit. I also need a laptop and a projector with a screen. A birdwatching camera setup is also needed so when the children go on the birdwatching walk they can snap some photos of the birds on their school grounds. A printer is also needed to create the materials that will be given to the children. 
  • You can be a major sponsor  with your name prominently mentioned in the presentation and in all advertising materials with your contribution of $5,000
  • Donations of $30 will buy a birding guide and the first 30 donors will have their name out in one of the books noting that it was your donation that made the book possible. Binoculars are $200 ea.  The first 30 donors who contribute this amount will have their name placed on one of the 30 binoculars needed so that each child is able to use one.  The projector ($1,300) and screen ($400) will cost approximately $1,700 and if you donate that amount first, your name will always be mentioned as the person who made that equipment possible. Then there's the laptop with the programs to create the slide shows and that's about $3,500.  The most expensive part of this program, but the item that will last the longest is the camera, lens and tripod/gimbal combination needed for birdwatching photography.  The total is about $16,000.  Then there is protective items for the equipment and cases to carry all the equipment from place to place and the printer to create all the materials that will be handed out to children at the presentations.  In any case, every single person who donates will be listed at the end of the program so that the students know that the presentation was made possible by the good will of many people who care for them. 
  • If you want to purchase the items directly and have them sent to me, we can do that as well.  I have specific brands that I've researched which will work the best for what I want to do, so if you are so inclined to purchase the item straight out from the specialty stores that I've researched, please let me know and I will give you the model number of the item and the store website that it is available from. And as previously mentioned, any item purchased with your donation will have your name on it stating you were the donor that made the item possible. You can contact me at roaemail@gmail.com for any question you may have.
  • I don't have much to offer besides my photography, so if there are any bird photos you like in my Facebook or Instagram I can send you an 8x10 of it for every $50 contribution. Just let me know which one by taking a screenshot and sending me an email to roaemail@gmail.com. I am grateful for anything you can donate and I can also sign the photo for you if you'd like. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help me get children going outdoors and walking and exercising. 

  • I believe this is extremely important because I can give children skills that will last for a lifetime and they can use those for a healthier lifestyle. Waking outside and looking for birds will take them away from sitting inside playing video games, which I believe is a major contributor to children's obesity. 
  • Every time I've given a birding presentation children they all been positive and given me really great feedback. They write notes telling me they enjoyed the birds and some even go home and look for birds on their own. One child told me one time as I finished my presentation he wished he could go home with me because he liked the birds so much. 
  • We all know or have children in elementary school. Wouldn't it be great if they could learn something new and exciting like birdwatching. 

Risks & Challenges

I believe this is a worthy cause and my challenge will be in raising the money needed.  Once I have the funds, getting the equipment and pitching the project to schools will be the easy part. I know my son's former teachers were all very positive about the presentation the first time I told them about it and even other teachers who watched had be come back for their own classes.

  • I've always been a positive person and outgoing. If I do not meet my goal this time with the fundraising the funds info receive will make the initial purchase of binoculars and bird books and any other equipment that I can afford. I will continue trying to raise funds until I have everything I need to get e children the best presentation possible. I want to give my best to them so they know there are people out there who truly care about them and their health. 
  • I have about 4 months to get everything ready and I know I can accomplish this goal because I've done the presentations before and all I need is the equipment to start calling schools and offering my free program. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can, share the link on Facebook, Twitter and email to those you know.
  • Please share this story with everyone. I truly am grateful for any help you can give me, financial or otherwise.  Please share this link: http://igg.me/p/1300502/twtr/11017697
