story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Eli Willner, President of Trebuchet (a five-year old New York based services firm), originator of the TutorToot concept (this campaign!), a parent and a one-time teacher. My colleagues and I have long been concerned about the less-than-ideal state of education in the US and wondered what we could do about it.

When we were kids our parents always helped us with our homework. Without that help we might have just given up and fallen behind. But many kids today, especially from disadvantaged areas, don't have anyone they can turn to at home for homework help. And they can't afford to pay for tutors, either.

Our core team at Trebuchet was previously involved in the creation and launch of an online tutoring service. It occurred to us that we could leverage our experience and customize a similar service to provide surrogate "parent-like homework assistance", online, to kids who need it.

The key idea here is that this service will be self-sustaining because it will have a commercial as well as an altruistic side. We will charge those who can afford to pay and use part of our revenues to fund free services for those who cannot afford to pay. We will motivate our tutors to accept less or no pay when they're helping disadvantaged students by giving them priority when they're helping paying students.

Your participation in our campaign will enable us to help kids all over the country succeed by improving their out-of-school learning experience. We will start by improving education in America one student at a time. But as we grow we just might revolutionize education in America by creating large communities of teachers and students who will serve as a positive force in restoring America's preeminent educational position. Wouldn't it be awesome to be a part of something this huge?

What We Need and Why

We've been nurturing this idea for a while and have a well-thought out game plan. Our functional spec, business model and marketing approach have been completed and we have even designed most of our app screens.  We need your help to fund the following items in order to make the plan a reality.

  • Application development - We've designed and are going to code a really cool app that students will love and that will run on just about every smart phone, tablet and desktop PC out there. We've done development work of this scope before and will be working with development partners we're familiar with and confident in. 
  • IT infrastructure - We've selected our hosting partner - also familiar to us - and scoped out our initial IT infrastructure requirements. 
  • Market analysis - When it comes to determining the "sweet spot" for pricing the service to our paying customers we don't want to play guessing games. Nor do we want to take a seat-of-the-pants approach in determining the sweet spot for tutor compensation. The objective is to maximize the number of paying students and active tutors while maintaining enough of a margin to pay for the qualifying non-paying students and have some profit left over at the end of the day. The analysis has to be done scientifically, by professionals, so we will be engaging a market research firm to do it for us.
  • Publicity and marketing - We want to hit the ground running and gather a critical mass of students and tutors in as short a time as possible. We want to get the word out about the availability of the free service to organizations serving disadvantaged communities in as broad-based a manner as possible. That takes work and costs money.
  • Startup operating expenses

We seek to raise $75,000 with your help. That's not a small amount of money but given the scope of what we're trying to accomplish it's really a very frugal budget. We will be able to carry our other costs with current and future capital investments and our projected first year earnings and plan to be self-sustaining after that.

What if...

In the event we don't raise the full amount our fall-back plan will enable us to launch in scaled down fashion. We won't compromise on our primary objective of providing free "parent-like homework assistance" to disadvantaged kids. But we will spend less on infrastructure and marketing and scale back our projected growth numbers accordingly.

On the other hand if, with your support, we exceed our funding goal we will be able to accelerate our growth plan and reach more kids who need the free service (and of course more paying customers to help support it) more quickly. Our app Release 2 is already on the drawing boards and has tons of slick new features. With additional funds we can accelerate the process of getting Release 2 into the hands of students who will benefit from it the most.

What's In It for You?

The biggest reward for supporting our project is the knowledge that you are doing something concrete and meaningful to improve the quality of education in America. At a minimum you'll be helping individual underprivileged students. Changing lives, one by one. And if our project snowballs as we expect it to it can truly revolutionize our educational system! Thus, all Indiegogo contributors will be listed and recognized on our website in perpetuity. You will have played a pivotal role in this endeavor and you deserve to be enshrined forever on our Wall of Fame!

But we would like to express our gratitude in more concrete ways as well so we've assembled a tantalizing array of perks including,

  • A really nice pen/stylus
  • A clip-on mirror so you can see the face of... your own face!
  • Our "official issue" colorful company tee-shirt
  • And of course, an array of different subscription plans to the service - for kids in your own family and for kids who can't afford the service themselves

So, by funding us you are rewarding yourself nicely as well - a true win-win!

Service Details

Our model for an online homework platform is “cool”, light and suited primarily to ad hoc questions that need quick answers, with explanations - in short, that will help students with their homework just like Mom and Dad helped us.

Many students today want instant gratification – they often function in “last minute” mode and are reluctant to plan or pre-schedule even activities that they concede are necessary, such as school work or test preparation. Many students today are uninterested in formalities or hurdles of any kind that have to be overcome before getting the information they require. They will not tolerate impediments that stand between their needs and the satisfaction of those needs. Students, and especially teens, are notorious followers of the herd instinct. They seek to do what is popular among their peers; what is perceived as “cool”.

Our online homework platform is aimed at today’s student. After a brief one-time setup students merely have to select their subject (their grade level and other relevant details are already in the system) and enter their questions into a simple, user-friendly app that runs on all platforms.

The question is broadcast to a team of tutors qualified in the student’s grade level and subject. The student will typically receive a response within seconds of sending the question. Follow up questions are permitted; the goal is to provide gratification in as complete and quick a manner as possible.

The experience is designed to be appealing in every respect. In addition to providing clear, concise and accurate answers the app will have engaging graphics, a catchy name and “concept” and slick and memorable effects that enhance the cool factor without being obtrusive.

The Name

We're calling our service "Tutor Toot" to convey a sense of whimsy and fun and we're calling the student questions "toots" because they will be short and sweet; quick outreaches for assistance that will evoke near-instant responses. We hope the name catches on!


The State of Education in the US

Here’s some sobering data: despite lowering standards, about 20% of all students who enter high school in the USA never graduate. In some low-income areas a staggering 41% never graduate. [Data from “Public High School Four-Year On-Time Graduation Rates and Event Dropout Rates” US Department of Education, April 2014.] Contrast with Finland, for example, where only 7% of students don’t graduate. Not coincidentally, in Finland 30% of children receive extra help during their first nine years of school. It is clear that out-of-school learning (i.e. homework) is a critical component of the learning process – and that parents today are simply not able to supply that extra help.

The Teaching Model for Our Times

Students sometimes have difficulty focusing in traditional classroom settings but they may be more amenable to learning via the quick interactions that will be the norm on our platform, which resemble traditional parent-provided homework help. While this is not an educational panacea it should mitigate towards more effective learning, in conjunction with other improvements that are being made in the US educational system.

Free to Those with a Need and No Means

It is an unfortunate fact that often, the students most in the need of the kind of service our platform will provide cannot afford to pay for it. Our system introduces a major innovation to address this problem. It is built from the ground up to support provision of free services (of the same quality made available to paying customers) to students in depressed economic areas who cannot afford to pay for the service.

Our plan is to fund the free service in three ways.

  • First, we will pay the costs of offering the free service out of revenues from the paid service.
  • Second, we will lower our out-of-pocket costs for the free service by creating incentives for tutors to respond to free questions with little or no remuneration. We will do this by favoring those tutors with priority on paid questions.
  • Third, we will seek funding from public and private sources that provide grants to fund educational services in disadvantaged areas and we will work through local educational non-profits to leverage grants that may already be in place, in exchange for providing their students free access to our system.

Why Us?

Because our background and experience uniquely qualify us for this role.

  • We are a technology firm with experience building large, scalable client-server systems (that's tech speak for the kind of platform our online homework service will be)
  • We are a services firm with a client-centric corporate culture
  • We are parents ourselves and have personal experience with the difficulties of balancing our professional lives with the homework assistance needs of our children
  • Some of us are teachers and are pained at the price kids pay, and the price America pays, because too many kids are deprived of the learning help they need outside the school environment
  • Our core team was previously involved in the creation and launch of an online tutoring service and we know first-hand of the problems that can arise in such an undertaking - and we know their solutions

Risks & Challenges

Will They Come?

While we don't doubt that we can build it, the question is, will they come? That, of course, is the risk inherent in any new service offering. We are confident that we have a handle on the variables under our control but there are always variables that we can't control. Nonetheless our experienced team is doing their utmost to leave nothing to chance. We’re planning on advertising in online and print media, contacting schools and parent organizations directly and otherwise engaging in an aggressive outreach campaign. We’ve already established relationships with numerous non-profits that specialize in K-12 education and we will be leveraging those relationships to identify students who qualify for the free service.

And we believe the odds are in our favor. The team is really pumped about the potential of this project and really excited about this Indiegogo campaign!

The Business Model

We will engage a professional firm to assist us in our market analysis so that we charge our paying customers enough to cover our costs but not so much that we'll drive them away.They'll also help us determine how much to pay our tutors so that it's a worthwhile undertaking for them while not breaking the bank. There is always a risk that the professional firm will be wrong. But we'll be mitigating that risk ahead of time by selecting the firm very carefully and by watching our post-launch bottom line very closely, so that if errors were made we'll catch them and make adjustments quickly.

Competition

All successful businesses run the "copycat risk". But we pride ourselves on our creativity - that's how we came up with the idea and the implementation plan in the first place - and we intend to stay ahead of the competition by continually exercising our creativity and not resting on our laurels. You'll be amazed at some of the tricks that we have up our sleeve for the future! And of course we'll have "first mover advantage" in our favor as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope that you're impressed enough by our project to contribute to the maximum extent that you're able. And we'd like you to help by telling your friends about us as well. Please help us get out the word about this important project! Use email, use the Indiegogo share tools, use mail and pony express!

And if you can't contribute financially, that's ok - but we would still appreciate your assistance in spreading the word!

Thank you, thank you, thank you - and we hope to be able to meet as many as our contributors as possible over time so we can thank you all personally, too!


=========================

Frequently Asked Questions


General Service

1.  Will this be a simple “cheat” for students to avoid having to work on their homework themselves?

No, not at all! Tutors will be trained to guide students toward understanding the material and arriving at correct answers themselves – just like good parents help their kids!

2.  Can students select which tutors they want to direct their questions to?

In the initial release of the service students will be assigned the first available tutor from our highly qualified pool who is approved for the student’s grade level and subject. Tutors are identified by unique “handles” but are otherwise anonymous. Future releases of the service will allow students to specify by “handle” either a “preference” for a particular tutor (if that tutor is online he or she will be given an exclusive window in which to respond after which the question will be assigned to the general tutor pool) or a “requirement” for a particular tutor (if that tutor is offline or does not respond to the question within the exclusive window the question will be withdrawn and not be assigned to the general tutor pool).

3.  How will students be protected against improper tutor contacts?

Prospective tutors will undergo extensive background checks by a reputable nationwide agency specializing in employment background checking and only tutors will clean records will be hired. Tutors will be instructed that all contacts with students must be maintained at the highest professional level and must not deviate into personal conversation and will be informed that indiscretions will result in immediate dismissal. All tutor-student interactions will be recorded and securely preserved and will be monitored by software in real-time to detect and flag potentially troublesome interactions. When these are detected a Tutor Toot staff member will review the interaction and terminate it immediately if it is problematic, following up with appropriate action aimed at the tutor and/or student.

4.  What grade levels and subjects will be covered by the service?

The initial release of the service will cover all subjects commonly taught in grades 6-12 in the USA. Future releases will also cover standard college prep and select college level courses.

5.  Will you support scheduled, longer-duration tutoring sessions as well as the “toot” concept?

The initial release of the service will focus on responding to ad hoc questions that typically arise when a student is doing homework, studying or reviewing school work at home. Future releases of the service will support scheduled longer-term learning sessions with student’s choice of tutor.

6.  What are the payment models for paying students?

Students will be able to pay per question (includes as much dialogue as necessary to resolve the question) or purchase a monthly subscription that will entitle them to an as-yet-to-be-determined (but substantial) amount of questions.

7.  What will the fees be for paying students?

The fee structure has not yet been determined but the goal is to make the service as affordable as possible for the paying students – if a student needs help we don’t want them to have to think twice before utilizing our service.

8.  Will you offer peer-to-peer (student to student) communication capability?

We are very interested in building a large opt-in community of both students and tutors who can dialogue outside the context of a formal “toot” or tutoring session and we plan to do so, once we work out an ironclad system to prevent abuse of the system and to protect our student and tutor members. This functionality will not be available in the initial release of the service.

9.  Will transcripts of tutoring dialogues be made available to outside parties?

All transcripts will be kept in strictest confidence in a secure offline facility and will be revealed to outside third parties only under legal compulsion. We are working on a permission-based set of rules that may allow for selective sharing of transcripts with parents, teachers and other parties with a legitimate interest in a student’s learning progress but this will not be available in the initial release of the service. We stress that no transcript will be released without student and parent explicit consent.

10.  What kinds of data will you be gathering about students and tutors?

Will we be monitoring tutor ratings with an eye to improving tutor effectiveness. We will also monitor the kinds of questions we are getting from students on an overall, regional and seasonal basis in order to better prepare our tutors for the kinds of questions they should be expecting, again, in order to improve tutor effectiveness. All data collected will be anonymized and under no circumstances will the questions of a particular student be shared with third parties.

11.  What determines which tutor will answer a student question?

The tutor assignment algorithm is as follows: the question is broadcast only to tutors who are online and have been certified in the grade and subject area of the question. For paying students, preference is given to tutors who most actively respond to qualifying free students, and the more active a tutor is in responding to those questions, the greater the preference that tutor receives. “Preference” means that those tutors have a brief window during which only they can “take” a question. However the primary objective is to get a response to the student as soon as possible so the window of exclusivity is small, and when it expires the question is broadcast to the entire tutor base (that is, all online tutors who are certified in the appropriate grade and subject area).

For non-paying students the question is immediately broadcast to the entire qualifying tutor base and no preference is given.

Once a tutor “takes” a question other tutors are locked out of taking it but if the “taking” tutor does not respond to the question within a very narrow response window, the question is returned to the tutor pool and other qualifying tutors may “take” it.

12.  What are the hours of operation?

Tutor Toot is intended to be an around-the-clock operation and we will have qualified tutors in all time zones to assure maximum coverage. Of course it is possible that at odd hours few qualified tutors will be available but we expect that to be a very rare occurrence, especially as the service and our tutor pool grow.

13.  How many questions are allowed on a “follow up” to an original question?

We do not intend to impose any limitation on follow-up questions. However tutors will have the discretion to terminate “toot” sessions when they determine that as much assistance as is educationally sound has already been provided and that further interaction will be non-productive.

14.  What role will parents, teachers, counselors, social workers and other parties interested in a student’s learning progress play in the Tutor Toot platform?

We are working on a permission-based set of rules that may allow for selective sharing of transcripts with parents, teachers and other parties with a legitimate interest in a student’s learning progress but this will not be available in the initial release of the service. We stress that no transcript will be released without student and parent explicit consent. For paying students, where parental consent is required for online purchases, it will be obtained.

Free Service

15.  How will you qualify students for the free service?

We will be working with local non-profits with a focus on education on a grass-roots level to identify qualified students. We will also be working, as appropriate, with local governments, schools and social service agencies to identify such students. Prior to our launch we will aggressively reach out to these organizations using traditional, electronic and social media to assure that they are aware of our service and know how to refer qualifying students to us.

16.  How will the free service be funded?

Our business model will enable us to allocate a portion of our profits from our paying service toward provision of the free service to qualifying students. To further broaden our reach we will also work to obtain funding from government agencies and private philanthropic organizations.

17.  How long will qualified students be able to use the service for free?

We will not impose arbitrary limitations on how long our service can be used by qualified students who are funded by Tutor Toot. We will re-evaluate student qualification for the free service on an annual basis and as long as a student meets the qualifications and is in a grade level serviced by Tutor Toot they will be able to utilize the service.

Students funded by outside organizations will be serviced as long as the funding for them continues. If it terminates and students formerly covered by them still require the service they will be given priority for internally funded free slots.

Tutors

18.  What qualifications will be required of tutors?

Tutors will need to demonstrate proficiency in the subjects and grade levels for which they wish to qualify. They will need to show that they have received training in those areas at a credentialed institute of higher learning, and/or prior experience teaching or tutoring in those areas. References will be sought and selectively verified. Tutors will also have to pass a Tutor Toot administered test before qualifying at a Tutor Toot tutor.

Prospective tutors will undergo extensive background checks by a reputable nationwide agency specializing in employment background checking and only tutors with clean records will be hired.

19.  How will tutors be screened before being hired?

Prospective tutors will undergo extensive background checks by a reputable nationwide agency specializing in employment background checking and only tutors will clean records will be hired.

20.  How will the tutor ratings be used?

Tutor ratings are intended as a tool to enable tutors to improve their performance and as a tool for Tutor Toot to assure that it is utilizing the services of only the best tutors. Periodically students who rate tutors will be sent optional surveys where they will be given the opportunity to elaborate on their tutor ratings and the results of these surveys, in anonymized form, will be shared with the tutors.

21.  What tools will you provide your tutors in order to streamline their question response process?

We will watching “question trends” on an overall, regional and seasonal basis and keep our tutors regularly informed as to what kinds of questions they should be expecting. In our initial release tutors will be able to build private libraries of common responses to frequently asked questions and will be able to utilize those “canned” answers as their initial response to student’s questions. (Of course the actual dialogue with the student after the initial response will be personalized and not reliant on canned information.)

In a future service release global libraries of responses to frequently asked questions will be developed and will be available to all tutors, in addition to their private libraries of responses.

22.  How much will the tutors be paid?

For paying students the tutors will be paid a percentage of the fee paid by the student (in the pay-as-you-go fee model) and a prorated percentage of the monthly fee based on the number of questions actually asked during that month. The payment model for tutors is currently being refined and will be finalized prior to the launch of the service.

23.  How will the tutors be paid?

Funds will accumulate in a tutor’s online Tutor Toot account and may be withdrawn at any time through payment into the tutor’s Paypal or other electronic payment account, or through direct deposit into a US bank account.

24.  Will the tutors be able to interact with one another?

We are very interested in building a large opt-in community of both students and tutors who can dialogue outside the context of a formal “toot” or tutoring session and we plan to do so, once we work out an ironclad system to prevent abuse of the system and to protect our student and tutor members. This functionality will not be available in the initial release of the service.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi, I'm Eli Willner, President of Trebuchet (a five-year old
New York based services firm), originator of the TutorToot concept (this campaign!), a parent and a one-time teacher. My colleagues
and I have long been concerned about the less-than-ideal state of education in
the US and wondered what we could do about it.
When we were kids our parents always helped us with our
homework. Without that help we might have just given up and fallen behind. But
many kids today, especially from disadvantaged areas, don't have anyone they
can turn to at home for homework help. And they can't afford to pay for tutors,
either.


Our core team at Trebuchet was previously involved in the
creation and launch of an online tutoring service. It occurred to us that we
could leverage our experience and customize a similar service to provide
surrogate "parent-like homework assistance", online, to kids who need
it.
The key idea here is that this service will be
self-sustaining because it will have a commercial as well as an altruistic
side. We will charge those who can afford to pay and use part of our revenues
to fund free services for those who cannot afford to pay. We will motivate our
tutors to accept less or no pay when they're helping disadvantaged students by
giving them priority when they're helping paying students.
Your participation in our campaign will enable us to help
kids all over the country succeed by improving their out-of-school learning
experience. We will start by improving education in America one student at a
time. But as we grow we just might revolutionize education in America by
creating large communities of teachers and students who will serve as a
positive force in restoring America's preeminent educational position. Wouldn't
it be awesome to be a part of something this huge?




What We Need and Why
We've been nurturing this idea for a while and have a
well-thought out game plan. Our functional spec, business model and marketing
approach have been completed and we have even designed most of our app
screens.  We need your help to fund the
following items in order to make the plan a reality.



Application development -
We've designed and are going to code a really cool app that students will love
and that will run on just about every smart phone, tablet and desktop PC out
there. We've done development work of this scope before and will be working
with development partners we're familiar with and confident in. 


IT infrastructure - We've
selected our hosting partner - also familiar to us - and scoped out our initial
IT infrastructure requirements. 


Market analysis - When it
comes to determining the "sweet spot" for pricing the service to our
paying customers we don't want to play guessing games. Nor do we want to take a
seat-of-the-pants approach in determining the sweet spot for tutor
compensation. The objective is to maximize the number of paying students and
active tutors while maintaining enough of a margin to pay for the qualifying non-paying students and have some profit left over at the end of the day. The analysis has
to be done scientifically, by professionals, so we will be engaging a market
research firm to do it for us.


Publicity and marketing -
We want to hit the ground running and gather a critical mass of students and
tutors in as short a time as possible. We want to get the word out about the
availability of the free service to organizations serving disadvantaged
communities in as broad-based a manner as possible. That takes work and costs
money.

Startup operating expenses

We seek to raise $75,000 with your
help. That's not a small amount of money but given the scope of what we're trying
to accomplish it's really a very frugal budget. We will be able to carry our
other costs with current and future capital investments and our projected first year earnings and
plan to be self-sustaining after that.
What if...
In the event we don't raise the full amount our fall-back
plan will enable us to launch in scaled down fashion. We won't compromise on
our primary objective of providing free "parent-like homework
assistance" to disadvantaged kids. But we will spend less on
infrastructure and marketing and scale back our projected growth numbers
accordingly. 
On the other hand if, with your support, we exceed our
funding goal we will be able to accelerate our growth plan and reach more kids
who need the free service (and of course more paying customers to help support
it) more quickly. Our app Release 2 is already on the drawing boards and has
tons of slick new features. With additional funds we can accelerate the process
of getting Release 2 into the hands of students who will benefit from it the
most.
What's In It for You?
The biggest reward for supporting our project is the
knowledge that you are doing something concrete and meaningful to improve the
quality of education in America. At a minimum you'll be helping individual
underprivileged students. Changing lives, one by one. And if our project
snowballs as we expect it to it can truly revolutionize our educational system!
Thus, all Indiegogo contributors will be listed and recognized on our website
in perpetuity. You will have played a pivotal role in this endeavor and you
deserve to be enshrined forever on our Wall of Fame! 
But we would like to express our gratitude in more concrete
ways as well so we've assembled a tantalizing array of perks including,



A really nice pen/stylus


A clip-on mirror so you can
see the face of... your own face!


Our "official
issue" colorful company tee-shirt


And of course, an array of
different subscription plans to the service - for kids in your own family and
for kids who can't afford the service themselves


So, by funding us you are rewarding yourself nicely as well
- a true win-win!


Service Details
Our model for an online homework platform is “cool”, light
and suited primarily to ad hoc questions that need quick answers, with
explanations - in short, that will help students with their homework just like
Mom and Dad helped us.
Many students today want instant gratification – they often
function in “last minute” mode and are reluctant to plan or pre-schedule even
activities that they concede are necessary, such as school work or test preparation.
Many students today are uninterested in formalities or hurdles of any kind that
have to be overcome before getting the information they require. They will not
tolerate impediments that stand between their needs and the satisfaction of
those needs. Students, and especially teens, are notorious followers of the
herd instinct. They seek to do what is popular among their peers; what is
perceived as “cool”. 


Our online homework platform is aimed at today’s student.
After a brief one-time setup students merely have to select their subject
(their grade level and other relevant details are already in the system) and
enter their questions into a simple, user-friendly app that runs on all
platforms.
The question is broadcast to a team of tutors qualified in the
student’s grade level and subject. The student will typically receive a
response within seconds of sending the question. Follow up questions are
permitted; the goal is to provide gratification in as complete and quick a
manner as possible.
The experience is designed to be appealing in every respect.
In addition to providing clear, concise and accurate answers the app will have
engaging graphics, a catchy name and “concept” and slick and memorable effects
that enhance the cool factor without being obtrusive.




The Name
We're calling our service "Tutor Toot" to convey a
sense of whimsy and fun and we're calling the student questions
"toots" because they will be short and sweet; quick outreaches for
assistance that will evoke near-instant responses. We hope the name catches on!






The State of Education in the US
Here’s some sobering
data: despite lowering standards, about 20% of all students who enter high
school in the USA never graduate. In some low-income areas a staggering 41%
never graduate. [Data from “Public High School Four-Year On-Time Graduation
Rates and Event Dropout Rates” US Department of Education, April 2014.] Contrast
with Finland, for example, where only 7% of students don’t graduate. Not
coincidentally, in Finland 30% of children receive extra help during their
first nine years of school. It is clear that out-of-school learning (i.e. homework)
is a critical component of the learning process – and that parents today are
simply not able to supply that extra help.

The Teaching Model for Our Times
Students sometimes
have difficulty focusing in traditional classroom settings but they may be more
amenable to learning via the quick interactions that will be the norm on our
platform, which resemble traditional parent-provided homework help. While this
is not an educational panacea it should mitigate towards more effective
learning, in conjunction with other improvements that are being made in the US
educational system.
Free to Those with a Need and No Means
It is an unfortunate fact that often, the students most
in the need of the kind of service our platform will provide cannot afford to
pay for it. Our system introduces a major innovation to address this problem.
It is built from the ground up to support provision of free services (of the
same quality made available to paying customers) to students in depressed
economic areas who cannot afford to pay for the service. 
Our plan is to fund the free service in three ways. 



First, we will pay the
costs of offering the free service out of revenues from the paid service.


Second, we will lower our
out-of-pocket costs for the free service by creating incentives for tutors to
respond to free questions with little or no remuneration. We will do this by favoring
those tutors with priority on paid questions.


Third, we will seek funding
from public and private sources that provide grants to fund educational
services in disadvantaged areas and we will work through local educational
non-profits to leverage grants that may already be in place, in exchange for
providing their students free access to our system.


Why Us?
Because our background and experience uniquely qualify us
for this role. 



We are a technology firm
with experience building large, scalable client-server systems (that's tech
speak for the kind of platform our online homework service will be)


We are a services firm with
a client-centric corporate culture


We are parents ourselves
and have personal experience with the difficulties of balancing our
professional lives with the homework assistance needs of our children


Some of us are teachers and are pained at the price kids pay, and the price America pays,
because too many kids are deprived of the learning help they need outside the
school environment


Our core team was
previously involved in the creation and launch of an online tutoring service
and we know first-hand of the problems that can arise in such an undertaking -
and we know their solutions


Risks & Challenges
Will They Come?
While we don't doubt that we can build it, the question is,
will they come? That, of course, is the risk inherent in any new service
offering. We are confident that we have a handle on the variables under our
control but there are always variables that we can't control. Nonetheless our
experienced team is doing their utmost to leave nothing to chance. We’re planning on
advertising in online and print media, contacting schools and parent organizations
directly and otherwise engaging in an aggressive outreach campaign. We’ve
already established relationships with numerous non-profits that specialize in
K-12 education and we will be leveraging those relationships to identify
students who qualify for the free service.
And we
believe the odds are in our favor. The team is really pumped about the
potential of this project and really excited about this Indiegogo campaign!
The Business Model
We will engage a professional firm to assist us in our
market analysis so that we charge our paying customers enough to cover our
costs but not so much that we'll drive them away.They'll also help us determine
how much to pay our tutors so that it's a worthwhile undertaking for them while
not breaking the bank. There is always a risk that the professional firm will
be wrong. But we'll be mitigating that risk ahead of time by selecting the firm
very carefully and by watching our post-launch bottom line very closely, so
that if errors were made we'll catch them and make adjustments quickly.
Competition
All successful businesses run the "copycat risk".
But we pride ourselves on our creativity - that's how we came up with the idea
and the implementation plan in the first place - and we intend to stay ahead of
the competition by continually exercising our creativity and not resting on our
laurels. You'll be amazed at some of the tricks that we have up our sleeve for
the future! And of course we'll have "first mover advantage" in our
favor as well.
Other Ways You Can Help
We hope that you're impressed enough by our project to
contribute to the maximum extent that you're able. And we'd like you to help by
telling your friends about us as well. Please help us get out the word about
this important project! Use email, use the Indiegogo share tools, use mail and
pony express!
And if you can't contribute financially, that's ok - but we
would still appreciate your assistance in spreading the word!




Thank you, thank you, thank you - and we hope to be able to
meet as many as our contributors as possible over time so we can thank you all
personally, too!

serviced as long as the funding for them continues. If it terminates and
students formerly covered by them still require the service they will be given
priority for internally funded free slots.

Tutors
18. 
What qualifications
will be required of tutors?
Tutors will need to demonstrate proficiency in the
subjects and grade levels for which they wish to qualify. They will need to
show that they have received training in those areas at a credentialed
institute of higher learning, and/or prior experience teaching or tutoring in
those areas. References will be sought and selectively verified. Tutors will
also have to pass a Tutor Toot administered test before qualifying at a Tutor
Toot tutor.
Prospective tutors will undergo extensive
background checks by a reputable nationwide agency specializing in employment
background checking and only tutors with clean records will be hired.
19. 
How will tutors be
screened before being hired?
Prospective tutors will undergo extensive
background checks by a reputable nationwide agency specializing in employment
background checking and only tutors will clean records will be hired.
20. 
How will the tutor
ratings be used?
Tutor ratings are intended as a tool to enable
tutors to improve their performance and as a tool for Tutor Toot to assure that
it is utilizing the services of only the best tutors. Periodically students who
rate tutors will be sent optional surveys where they will be given the
opportunity to elaborate on their tutor ratings and the results of these
surveys, in anonymized form, will be shared with the tutors.
21. 
What tools will you
provide your tutors in order to streamline their question response process?
We will watching “question trends” on an overall,
regional and seasonal basis and keep our tutors regularly informed as to what
kinds of questions they should be expecting. In our initial release tutors will
be able to build private libraries of common responses to frequently asked
questions and will be able to utilize those “canned” answers as their initial
response to student’s questions. (Of course the actual dialogue with the
student after the initial response will be personalized and not reliant on
canned information.)
In a future service release global libraries of
responses to frequently asked questions will be developed and will be available
to all tutors, in addition to their private libraries of responses.
22. 
How much will the
tutors be paid?
For paying students the tutors will be paid a
percentage of the fee paid by the student (in the pay-as-you-go fee model) and
a prorated percentage of the monthly fee based on the number of questions
actually asked during that month. The payment model for tutors is currently
being refined and will be finalized prior to the launch of the service. 
23. 
How will the tutors
be paid?
Funds will accumulate in a tutor’s online Tutor
Toot account and may be withdrawn at any time through payment into the tutor’s
Paypal or other electronic payment account, or through direct deposit into a US
bank account.
24. 
Will the tutors be
able to interact with one another?
We are very interested in building a large opt-in
community of both students and tutors who can dialogue outside the context of a
formal “toot” or tutoring session and we plan to do so, once we work out an
ironclad system to prevent abuse of the system and to protect our student and
tutor members. This functionality will not be available in the initial release
of the service.

story:
Since 2004, a Bangladeshi/Norwegian project has contributed to strengthen the folk song tradition of poverty stricken people in Bangladesh. The organization which runs this project in Bangladesh is called Arshi Nagar and is being supported by our organization SUNO in Norway. The project area is the two districts of Lalmonirhat and Kurigram, including moving sand islands in the Brahmaputra River. Music is one of few artistic expressions that lightens a daily life of hardship in this flood-prone area.

Now we need your help to ensure the continuation of one of these project activities:

Due to political reasons in Norway, we are losing some of our financial support in 2015 which will harm the musical instrument training component. With the potential amount we will receive through crowd funding, we will be able to continue the training in all the different music schools, the gurugrihos. We will also have the opportunity to repair and upgrade the instruments which are being used for teaching. This is at the same time maintenance of valuable traditional instruments.

The project’s main components are as follows:

a) Establish and run village music “schools” where children aged seven to sixteen – boys and girls, Muslims and Hindus – learn to sing and play traditional music that was about to disappear. Each school has two teachers, usually one Hindu and one Muslim. The musical forms are: bhabaya/polygit, murshidi, baul, and Lalan git (songs by the famous poet Lalan Fakir). The traditional instruments are: ektara (from ek “one” and tar “string”), dotara (literally, two strings, but in practice often more), khamak, sarinda (a fiddle-like instrument), and dhol (drums). Each school has its own set of basic instruments, including a harmonium and tabladrums for the teaching of scales/modes and rhythm. So far, 17 village schools have been set up, most of them with 20 to 25 pupils, who attend for at least two afternoons a week. In many cases they attend every day.

b) Organize large or small meals, or festivals. This is being organized every year. One year we gathered all of the musical elders. On that occasion, during a time of
Emergency Rule, 150 singers and musicians – Hindus and Muslims, men and women – came from all corners of the large districts in order to sing in the town of
Lalmonirhat.

c) Archive the traditional music and songs, write down the songs of the oldest singers, and ensure that the children learn these while master teachers are still available.

d) Run the Arshi Nagar Sound Studio, which we have built and equipped in the
town of Lalmonirhat. There is no other sound studio in Northern Bangladesh. In
this studio, CDs have been produced. These may generate some little income for
some of the musicians, but above all the CDs provide the pleasure of giving
something to their country (and their language!), and of seeing that traditions
which were about to disappear will survive after all.

The SUNO Project has been run with donations from Norway, which are used entirely to pay the Bangladeshis who work on the project, to buy instruments, and to give aid in the case of medical or other crises.  
 

Other ways you can help

Tell people about us and find out more at our website: www.suno-norge.org

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Registered NGO:

 Suno-Norway is a member of the Norwegian Register of Non-Profit  Organizations (http://www.brreg.no/english/registers/frivillighet/) which is similar to beeing registered as a so called 501(c)(3) in the United States.

story:
I have worked as an English, Spanish and German as a Second Language teacher striving to help people of different nationalities and backgrounds understand each other for most of my working life. I am a Chilean national who was fortunate to get an international school education. I have a passion for foreign languages, which combined with my education, ultimately led to my having the chance to work and develop in this field, even though I never completed my university studies. But I never lost hope I would someday fulfill that dream and accomplish that goal.

Along the way, life happened. My daughter was born and her accomplishments became my goal, first and foremost.  As a single mother I have been very fortunate, my daughter is a wonderful human being. She has had a good education, majored in Acting, and has continued studying to further her education and help others lead happier lives.

For the past nine years, I worked in the international office at one of Chile’s
largest universities. For many years I was in charge of international students
coming to study in Chile, as well as international university partnerships and
dual-degree programs. I could have stayed there but I felt I still had something to achieve in this lifetime: I had to complete my own education.  I discovered I might have a chance of doing just that in my field in Germany, where public university is basically tuition-free. There are some other expenses to pay but no tuition. I applied as an international student to three major universities and was accepted into two of them – places for international students in Humanities are limited – about 5% of the total enrollment in the field for the academic year. So I tendered my resignation in Chile and was compensated for the years I had worked at the university. With this money I was able to organize my relocation to Berlin, enroll in the Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, and lead a decent student’s life up until now.

It has not been easy. I had to leave my daughter, my life as I’d known it, my
surroundings, my friends and family, my comfort zone, ...and begin from scratch.  I am lucky to have loving, supportive friends here too but now I need help to stay here and continue.  I am actively looking for a part-time job and have been doing translations to earn a living but time is running out, as are my savings.

I need to find financial resources to continue living here. As a foreigner with a
Student’s Visa, I can work part-time for up to 8 months out of a year. It’s
complicated but not impossible. I need to study and pass my exams, and I need
to work and earn my living. I will fulfill my dream!

I am grateful to you for reading my story. I am grateful to you for helping me
get there in any way that you can.  I appreciate your positive energy, and if you can help me financially or by passing my crowdfunding request along to others who may be in a position to help me, I thank you.

story:
Autism is common mental disorder which can be difficult to live with. Everyday things which are easy for us can be very difficult to handle for a person with autism. This mental disorder is unfortunately quite common. More common than most people think.

About 3 to 4 in 1,000 children and youngsters have an autism spectrum disorder, which equates in the Netherlands to about 12,000 children and youngsters. The best known and most common form is "classic" autism, then PDD-NOS and Asperger are sharing the second place.

Professional counselors today know very much and often offer proper guidance and support. But maybe sometimes they forget the value of the knowledge and experience of the "experts", people with autism, forgotten. "It takes one to know one" here is perhaps an appropriate expression.

After all, they know best which difficulties they encounter in day to day life and sometimes as well as how to handle them.

Therefore, I want to develop an app allow for and (partly) by children and adolescents of about 11 to 21 years old with an autism spectrum disorder, named Autism Coach.

The purpose of the app is that some young people with autism can be more independent and get more out of their lives. For example independently being able to do groceries, walk the dog, going to school or daycare.

Autism Coach is not only for the youngsters themselves, but also to include parents, caregivers, social workers and teachers.

For more information check the official website of Autism Coach.

Please support us and follow us at Twitter: @AutismeApp , Facebook, (Personal) LinkedIn and Google+.

Autism Coach is an initiative of Coachingsbureau 'Coaching met een tintje', from Leiden, the Netherlands 

Twitter: @mental_coaching, Facebook, (Business) LinkedIn, Google+

Thank you very much! 

One Love

Jay

story:
A Little About Us

My name is Mike Pugh and I am the Executive Director of Above All Adventures, which serves teens 13-19 in Placer and Nevada counties. I created Above All Adventures to give back to teens some of the life skills that I have learned as an adult, such as team building, goal-setting, learning how to succeed and fail, and how to  learn from your failures. I want to help teens find their passion and vision for their lives, and learn "how" to accomplish that goal. It's important for our teens to become part of our community and be future leaders, and to do this we need our "community" to support these teens. Many of the teens in our community are at risk with 25% lacking a supportive, caring adult in their lives. Depression rates are high in both counties, with 34% of 11th grade girls experiencing depression in Nevada County and 32% in Placer County. For boys, it is 25% and 21% respectively. Our teens need support and some inspiration so they know they are capable of planning successful and happy lives.

Early last year, we had an Indiegogo campaign to raise funds to file our non-profit status and build our website.  We received our non-profit status in November and our website is up and running!  We are now launching our second campaign to give us the final push to open our doors and begin our experiential seminars and outdoor programs this summer. 

What We Need From You

We are seeking $10,000 in start-up funding to help us open our office doors! Following are our funding needs:

- open our office (rent, remodeling, furniture, phones, utilities)
- hire staff
- prepare materials for the experiential seminars
- provide insurance
- purchase office supplies and equipment
- lease a vehicle for transporting the teens to the outdoor adventure programs)
- prepare marketing material
- promote our new non-profit
- provide subsidized class fees for low-income teens

Some Cool Incentives:
We appreciate and are grateful for every contribution.  As a new non-profit, this campaign will give us the final push to open our doors so we can achieve our mission "to encourage and inspire young people, through experience in seminars and outdoor adventures, to challenge themselves and become leaders."  Thank you for being part of our community of supporters! All of our supporters will receive a thank you letter with an update and option to receive our newsletter and stay in touch.  For those supporters who are able to contribute $500 or more, we'll also send you one of our awesome t-shirts so you can proudly boast about Above All Adventures!


How Your Contribution Impacts Teens from Placer and Nevada Counties
Since our last Indiegogo campaign, we have been meeting with many community partners who have confirmed the need for a non-profit to help teens transition into being successful adults in our area.  We have interested schools, church groups, and other community partners who have youth who would benefit from our program and are looking for summer programs. We need the additional funds to cover the seminar materials, insurance, and marketing of our program - so we can open our office doors early this summer. With your contribution, we can make the transition from start-up to delivering our first program and building our momentum for future programs and consistent funding as an established non-profit. Our community partners include:

        

Tahoe Truckee Collaborative ~  Youth Empowerment Support ~ Placer Collaborative Network ~ Placer County Health & Human Services ~ Nevada County Health & Human Services ~ Parkside Community Church ~ Chana High School ~ Kids First ~ Pride Industries ~ Courageous Connection/Evolve You Foundation ~ Placer Coalition of Youth ~ Tahoe Truckee Foundation ~ Placer Community Foundation ~ Community Support Network of Nevada County ~ Center for Nonprofit Leaders ~ Nonprofit Resource Center ~ Placer County Sheriffs ~ Nevada County Sheriffs ~ Grass Valley Police Department ~ Rocklin Police Department ~ City of Roseville Police Department ~ Boys & Girls Clubs ~ Campaign for Community Wellness ~ News, Events & Opportunities - NEO ~ Placer County Office of Education.

Challenges

The biggest hurdle we face this year is obtaining funds from corporate giving programs or foundations because we are a new non-profit.  Our charge this year is to: build our community support, deliver three summer programs and eight fall programs, and boost our marketing and visibility in the community.  Your contributions allow us to achieve this goal. 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to make a contribution to our campaign, you can still be one of our community of supporters!  

  • Please share this campaign with your friends and family. 
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools - you can share it on Facebook with your friends and family.
  • Sign up to receive our newsletter so you can see our progress!  We would love to "keep you in the loop" so you can continue to be one of our supporters! 
  • We need office equipment and supplies. If you have some donations, let us know and we'll let you know what we need!
  • Please let us know if your company has a matching donation program. 

Be sure to check out our website

www.abovealladventures.org

story:
Short Summary

Project Video: A small clip from last years Runway 7.0 show, themed Chrysalis, with collection by senior designer, and friend, Meghan McNicholl. Each show includes individual student designers and concludes with the senior projects, one of them shown here.

Hello! I am a SUNY Buffalo College student studying apparel design. My last year here, I must showcase my final collection in the annual runway, held at my college. The final project/runway, requires each student to go through a process similar to preparations for a real fashion show. For an academic year, I research trends and, in collaboration with the ultimate theme for runway (this year is innovation), I design a trend, color, fabric, pattern, and line board with 6 outfits. The next steps are recruiting models, making patterns, drafts, then completed garments. There are many other smaller steps in the process, but the main goal is to get my 6 garments on the runway.

My collection is inspired by recent trends involving lace intimates evolved into evening/formal wear, such as indie brand, For Love and Lemons. My collection targets the ability to transform intimates one usually wears around the house into elegant, but comfortable outfits for all outings. The innovation aspect lies in the ability to allow women to be comfortable at all times and still look elegant; to transform the 'rolled out of bed' look into something desirable.

As a college student, I need help funding my project, as it requires much material and supplies. If any funds come my way, I'll put it towards purchasing yards of fabric, lace, zippers, lining, and other sewing essentials and supplies, shoes, accessories, and hair and makeup products for my models. Challenges that might occur after my project has been funded, is that I might waste the money on accidentally purchasing the wrong fabric. To overcome this, I've decided to purchase swatches of the fabric, first, before I commit to bulk. Also, to make the most of the money funded, so that I don't waste/run out, I will purchase fabric and supplies at the most reasonable price I can find. When I'm completed with my collection, and it walks down the runway at the end of the year, I will be able to put this collection towards my college portfolio, which will help me build my resume for future careers/internships! I'm very excited to start this project and hope it peaks some interest in fellow GOGOs who love fashion as much as I do. I'd be thankful for even the smallest contribution! It would help, a lot, even to share my campaign with others! And, please, if you're in the Buffalo, NY area, you're welcome to attend this fashion show, on April 25th. More information can be found on the college website, here: runway.buffalostate.edu.

To overcome this, I've decided to purchase swatches of the fabric, first, before I commit to bulk. Also, to make the most of the money funded, so that I don't waste/run out, I will purchase fabric and supplies at the most reasonable price I can find. When I'm completed with my collection, and it walks down the runway at the end of the year, I will be able to put this collection towards my college portfolio, which will help me build my resume for future careers/internships! I'm very excited to start 
this project and hope it peaks some interest in fellow GOGOs who
 love fashion as much as I do. I'd be thankful for even the smallest 
contribution! It would help, a lot, even to share my campaign with others! And, please, if you're in the Buffalo, NY area, you're 
welcome to attend this fashion show, on April 25th. More information can
 be found on the college website, here: runway.buffalostate.edu.

story:
Angolan Christian Academy 


     

One man had a dream to bring a school to the children in a rural village in Angola. Having fled persecution in Angola, he is now a pastor in Philadelphia.  After sharing his dream with a retired American contractor, his dream was given new hope.  

This two man team went to Angola to find a location for their school.  A ten acre site in Benquela Province was given to them by the government, inland from the  port city of Lobito.  Plans have been drawn for a campus with six buildings around a courtyard (see photo).  Included in the buildings will be ten classrooms, office space, staff quarters, a kitchen area, bathrooms and a chapel.  The courtyard will include a playground, an area for sports and a picnic area for daily meals.  Future plans include housing for orphans.


Funding for the campus 

The six buildings will be built of concrete block in a hexagon shape, the outside back walls will enclose the campus for security.  The plan is to begin with one building, estimated to cost $64,000, which includes the cost of all construction materials, tools and a vehicle.  The school could potentially serve as many as 500 children in two shifts at it's completion.  We are asking for your participation with us in funding the Angolan Christian Academy.  Because of a group of volunteers, there are no overhead costs.   All funds will go directly to the building of the school and are tax deductible.  

ACA has a excellent, qualified executive staff.  Our Executive Director, Sozinho Alves, a native of Angola, now pastor of a church in Philadelphia, PA., has many ties to the area in Lobito.  He will provide the care and oversight of the school.  

Filomena Assis, who serves as Director of College Renaissace, Angola, who has been serving the Benguela school systems for several decades,  lives in Lobito and will act as Superintendent and help with curriculum, teacher pool and school operations.

American Paul Peterson, for 40 years owner of Fourth Generation Builders, Wisconsin, is responsible for the construction and maintenance of the school and property.  He will ensure that the project funds are spent carefully and that the project is built to the highest standards in a timely manner.

The Board of Directors is made up of professionals from both the US and Angola.  They will provide oversight of the development and funding of the school.  Quarterly audits by an independent accounting firm will ensure that all funds go directly towards Angolan Christian Academy expenses.

Our Mission Statement

The purpose of the Angolan Christian Academy is to provide a safe, caring school environment where the village children can find a quality Christian education, to train our students in the arts and sciences and to nurture them in the faith of Christ so they are challenged to think well and live well and do both for the glory of God and in service to each other. 

Our Vision

Our vision is to help build young men and women of character and integrity prepared to assume their roles in their families, their communities as well as participate in the future progress of their nation.  Housing for orphans is planned for future developement.

Ways You Can Help

We have joined Indiegogo as a way of sharing the need for a school for the village children of Angola where no schools exist.  We are asking for prayers, not just money.  So if you can help us in either or both ways, you would be joining in making the lives of hundreds of children richer and one little girl will learn to read her book. Thank you and God bless you.

story:
The International Human Rights Association of American Minorities (IHRAAM) is a Non-Governmental Organization  in Consultative Status with the United Nations.

IHRAAM has filed an historic Alternative Report with the UN Human Rights Council, outlining the disproportionate cutbacks and problematic policies that are sending Black education reeling throughout the USA. The US is literally knocking the supports out from under African American K-12 schools and the 106 Historically Black Colleges & Universities (HBCUs) that provide 40-60% of African American STEM (Science, Technical, Engineering and Medical) higher education.  These schools are key to the economic sustainability and political vitality of African American heartland communities. These actions could condemn African Americans to form a permanent underclass in the United States.

In May 2015, when the UN Human Rights Council undertakes its scheduled quadrenniel Universal Periodic Review of Human Rights in the United States, IHRAAM needs to be there to appeal to the UNHRC, other nations and NGOs to pressure the US to refund Black education, and ensure the equal-status economic survival of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) throughout the USA.

To that end, IHRAAM seeks to send a diverse cadre of African American human rights attorneys and HBCU officials to the UN's Palais des Nations in Geneva, Switzerland and conduct a side-session event to lay bare the issues for all to see. The IHRAAM team is working for free.  But we need your help to raise $6.5K for airfare and accommodations.

story:
Feeding the mind and nourishing the body...

A few of the industry’s top chefs in the Atlantic City area are banding together to teach at-risk youth basic culinary and life skills.  These students come from all imaginable walks of life including: poverty, addiction, and domestic violence. 

Chefs with a Mission has partnered with an inner city church, the Community Food Bank of New Jersey, and other community outreach programs says Rev. David M. McGettigan of St. Andrews by the Sea, to create a training oasis for at-risk inner-city youth.  Here these kids can develop and learn lifelong skills that provide a serious alternative to a life condemned to poverty.   

How you can help. Donate $5, $10,  $100 or any amount you can spare.

Current, our facility and class programs are self-funded and these professional chefs are all volunteers, but the program is growing.  To meet these needs and expenses, and broaden services, we are raising funds to help keep up with the demand.

That’s where you come in.  

What can you do? HELP US REACH OUR $5,000 match goal to support the next set of classes and students.

Every gift donation will be matched up to $5,000.  Thanks to the generosity of a local philanthropist, the goals and vision of this training program can continue to grow only if others are willing to step in and assist. 

What’s Arugula or Egg Plant? Many inner-city kids have never seen one much less know how to prepare it.  Your support will feed and teach at-risk-youth how to support themselves for a lifetime! 

Currently Atlantic City faces severe economic hardship as local business and the travel and hospitality industry look to re-invent Atlantic City and restore jobs to the community.  But this is not a problem that inner-city kids should ever face. Our goal is to provide continued life development skills, proper nutrition and career opportunities despite the economic downturn. Fortunately Chefs with a Mission together with Reverend David and the parishioners of St. Andrews are taking an active stance by creating this facility to insure these kids get that second change.  Won’t you help?

“Give a kid a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.”

Help teach kids to fish for a lifetime… Make a support Donation Now! 

Underprivileged families face basic challenges in preparing and feeding their families every day.  By also drawing attention to their malnutrition plight, Chefs with a Mission hopes more people will get involved with them, as they take on these serious challenges through training and education programs.  Our goal is to ensure struggling families are getting better nutrition and greater access to food resources available in their community. 

Ways You Can Help:

MAKE A DONATION. Every dollar that is give will help bring smiles of confidents, smiles of love and smiles that come from having a full and nourishing meal… one that can create at home or a place of future employment.  MAXIMIZE YOUR IMPACT NOW WITH OUR MATCHING GIFT DONOR.
SHARE. Help create more awareness for our reading and teaching youth training program by sharing it with your friends and family on Facebook or Twitter. 
VOLUNTEER. We are always looking for more volunteer chefs to help with program. Visit our website to learn more.

story:
What is Growing Minds Center?

Growing Minds Center is a small school dedicated to bettering the lives of children with Autism and other disabilities, with a focus on helping the kids to be able to live in mainstream society. Located in the small town of Port Saint Joe, Florida, we are the only school that specializes in Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) in the Tri-County area. Seeing these kiddos grow, learn, and thrive in a way that they never have before is extremely rewarding and makes a job that might seem difficult endlessly worthwhile. Our staff is like a family and the kids are the heart of it.

This indiegogo campaign and the money we hope to raise from it will help us in a number of ways. From providing our school with basic, yet necessary supplies to saving for a new building with more space.. every little bit that we raise will go towards the education of these very special kids.

What is Applied Behavior Analysis?

Behavior analysis is a practice that focuses on the principles that explain how learning takes place. The point of Applied Behavioral Analysis is to provide techniques for more useful behaviors and less harmful ones. Positive reinforcement is an example - when a behavior is followed by a reward, the behavior is more likely to happen again. Applied behavior analysis uses these techniques to aid in a meaningful and positive change in behavior. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our set goal will be used for school materials, small field trips, therapy tools, and reinforcers for the kids. Any extra we make will go towards saving for our "Someday" Wish List.
  • Our "Someday" Wish List: A larger school facility, a transportation van, playground equipment, therapeutic play equipment, field trip funds, a touchscreen computer, iPads, and more staff members!
  • As a perk to donating to our cause, we have handcrafted gifts by our students including autism hair bows, Christmas ornaments, a penguin family winter decoration, a pack of Christmas cards, and a thank you video with a Christmas carol!

The Impact

Because Growing Minds Center is a non-profit organization, our staff salaries, location rental, and utilities are funded by the scholarship tuition of our students. What is left over we use for materials but a a whole, our entire center is functioning because of donations. Our employees have a passion for our students and a large portion of our donations come from within our own team. Daily, we donate our time, creativity, and money to make this center run.
Unfortunately, each of us can only do so much. This is where you come in. We are reaching out to the community to donate to this very worthy cause. We facilitate the learning of those with special needs and are in great need ourselves. Please consider enriching the environment of the children and aiding in renovation and expansion of the materials necessary to guide these young minds. In doing so, the impact you will have on the lives of our students, their families, our staff & their families will continue to overflow in a ripple effect. We would greatly appreciate any help you can spare! 
About Our Staff
We have two amazing administrators, a Behavior Analyst consultant, six full-time staff members, four graduate students from Florida State University, a part-time Occupational Therapist, Physical Therapist, Speech Therapist, and many wonderful volunteers and parents.

Risks & Challenges

We are a small school smack-dab in the middle of a tiny southern town, meaning that our biggest challenge is going to include getting the word out about our campaign. We are going to overcome this as a team by doing the footwork to advertise as much as possible. Between our team, our wonderful group of parents, and the groundbreaking people from Indiegogo, we believe our worthy cause will get the attention and support that it deserves. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, we'd still appreciate your help:

  • We know that it's not always possible for people to donate and that's okay! If you believe in our goal as much as we do, all we ask is that you help to get the word out and make some noise about our project.
  • Check out the Indiegogo share tools and be sure to share and post on Facebook, Twitter and any other social media about our cause!

Thank you for taking this journey with us!

<3 Growing Minds Center

story:
Rosie's Theater Kids

RTKids is an arts education organization dedicated to enriching the lives of children through the arts.  RTKids was founded in 2003 by Rosie O’Donnell as a way to transform the lives of underprivileged children through arts education.  RTKids is based in New York City and serves thousands of children in the New York area every year through in-school programs and programs at the Maravel Arts Center.

Students involved in the programs not only gain training in the arts; they also gain confidence, pride, discipline, and a sense of personal accomplishment.  RTKids teaches children how to strive for excellence and achieve their goals.  That’s why their motto is “Rosie’s Theater Kids- We’re Rehearsing for Life”.  These programs have proven successful at improving academic results, and RTKids has achieved a 100% high school graduation rate for all students participating in programs at the Maravel Arts Center.

The Atlanta Project

I am facilitating a one-week residency of RTKids in Atlanta.  We will be working with the entire 5th grade class of two underserved Atlanta elementary schools February 18-21.  The Atlanta project will consist of an abbreviated version of the current PS Broadway program, the in-school program in the New York area. 

UPDATE: Toomer Elementary School in East Lake and Briar Vista Elementary near Emory will be the two schools participating in the project.

Each individual 5th grade class will have one 45-minute lesson in dance, music and performance Wednesday-Friday, Feb. 18-20 taught by Thecla Harris, the Artistic Director of PS Broadway in New York, and accompanied by a RTKids pianist.  On Saturday, Feb. 21, there will be a final performance at SCADShow (formerly 14th Street Playhouse) for family, friends, and community members, where the kids will display the skills they’ve learned. 

As part of this program, schools also receive theater tickets to take the entire 5th grade on a field trip to see an age-appropriate show the Alliance Theater, as well as funds to help cover the cost of bus transportation.  

Your Contribution

UPDATE: We need $2,700 to make the RTKids Atlanta Project a reality.  The project has recently received some generous outside donations and $6,000 is our stretch goal to provide additional RTKids services to underserved children.  We have already raised enough money to get RTKids down to Atlanta for the residency, but now we need your help to provide the children with the full experience.

With your help, we will be able to secure a venue for the final performance, purchase theater tickets for the children, and transportation for their field trip to the show. 

Your contribution to this campaign is 100% tax deductible and goes directly towards supporting the arts education of Atlanta students.

As an added bonus, The Lovett Foundation has agreed to match up to the first $2,500 raised in this campaign.

The money you donate will help bring this proven program to Atlanta kids, and start delivering the kind of results experienced with the New York Rosie’s Theater Kids program. I hope you’ll join us in discovering the joy of changing kids’ lives with your donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to get involved with the Rosie's Theater Kids Atlanta Project?  We'd love to have you!

UPDATE: If you're in the Atlanta area, please join us for a free workshop and discussion with Thecla Harris, Artistic Director of PS Broadway, on Wednesday, February 18 at 4:00 on the Emory University campus.  1602 Fishburne Drive, Room 205, Atlanta, GA 30322

We need:

  • Volunteer Teaching Assistants to work with Thecla Harris in-school February 18-20 and during the final performance on February 21.
  • A restaurant sponsor (or ambitious volunteers) to provide a healthy meal for the children before their final performance on February 21.  

Thank you!

We would like to thank our sponsor at Fifth Third Bank Broadway in Atlanta for the generous ticket donation.
Fifth Third Bank Broadway in Atlanta is the premier presenter of touring Broadway productions in Atlanta. Over the past 34 years, more than 3 million guests have enjoyed more than 160 Broadway In Atlanta shows at the historic Fox Theatre in Midtown Atlanta.  To learn more, visit BroadwayInAtlanta.com.  
Special thanks to:
The Lovett Foundation
The Emory University Department of Film and Media Studies
Theater Emory and Janice Akers
Rosie's Theater Kids
Colin Niebergall
Jordan Flowers
